Review Title: A visit to the Glenloch Tea estate
Review Text: Tea plants thrive in a specific combination of ideal climate, diverse geography, rich soil, and consistent rainfall. Sri Lanka’s central highlands offer these perfect conditions: high altitudes provide cool temperatures, high humidity, and plentiful, well-distributed rain to hydrate the vegetation. It is this "Goldilocks zone" that allows the slow growth necessary for complex flavors to develop in high-quality tea leaves. A visit to the Glenloch Tea estate immerses you in this environment, featuring a tour of the lush tea fields, the intricate leaf processing factory, and a tasting session. Afterward, guests can explore a well-stocked, if relatively expensive, gift shop to purchase their favorite blends.

As a tea lever I enjoyed my one on my one tour here. The tour started with a visit inside the factory. From here we went outside into the tea plantation where I had a small look into the life of a picker. My last stop was a visit to the cafe where I was treated to a tasting of 4 different teas. Make sure you treat your self to a cholesterol or other treat too! I finished my tour off with a visit to the shop to purchase some tea to take home with me to Australia. The tour itself was free, I just tipped my lovely guide!

Review Title: A fun visit for both tea and non-tea drinkers alike
Review Text: The tour of the factory was informative and engaging, complete with a tea tasting and chance to dress up and try our hand at plucking tea leaves.

Review Title: Magnificent experience.  Work and smiles. Sri Lanka on this visit.
Review Text: Being greeted by a kind person who accompanied us to the factory explaining carefully all the processing procedures and the methods and machinery used could already be worth the visit. But shaking hands with the people who responded to our greeting during their work was even more beautiful.  There is a tourist and marketing part that consists of proposing to buy sweets to associate with the tea that you will taste and that you will later be invited to buy. But honestly the thing is not too insistent; moreover for us who were accompanied by a local driver there was no entrance fee but only a final free offer. Therefore also assessable based on purchases made or not. The view of the plantations is a magnificent panorama and having been able to try to pick tea in typical dress is something I will never forget. Thank you.

Review Title: If you get to visit the estate might be worth it. Else avoid.
Review Text: We reached there a bit late, around there closing time. The lady who escorted us gave all the info about the working of the factory. Gave us a few kinds of tea to try. Bought BOPF type and it is absolutely horrible. Total waste of money. I get better tea here in India at a better rate.

Not being a tea drinker I honestly didn't think that I would get anything from the tour experience at the tea factory but was i so wrong I had a great time learning about different teas and how the leaves are picked by hand and dried and then ground the lady that showed us around was awesome ( sorry I forgot your name but see pictures) . I didn't like the tea tasting but in all honesty I drink coffee as my preference however others in my party love it.

Review Title: Authentic private tours around a fascinating factory
Review Text: This tea factory hasn't got a lot of publicity but is excellent.  we had our own guide just for the 2 of us - and the tour was fascinating.  Some very old machinery both from Scotland and England and incredibly preserved.  Fascinating tour and then we got to taste tea and pick the tea with the baskets on heads - super tour

We stopped here on our travels,  we were met by a friendly lady who showed us around explaining all the processes in tea making. We even had a go at picking the tea leaves with traditional baskets. Great experience well worth a visit.

Recommend this experience, Your guide takes you through the factory, explains the process. You have a tasting, and then venture into the plantation, where you can try your hand at plucking ! Not at all crowded, a great experience.

Lovely Tea Factory.  It was great to see the original 150 year old factory, with all the original machinery.  Everyone was really nice and we had a tea tasting at the end.  Huge shop with lots of Tea's to take home.

We stopped by on the off chance of a tour and were pleased to find that it wasn’t too busy. The tour guide took her time with us, explaining each step of the process in English. Then we had the chance to sample the teas and walk around the shop before going outside to pluck tea ourselves. They also offered our driver a cup while he waited for us. The kids (12 and 9) enjoyed it too!
The old English sorting machines are still doing their job. The team also added a new machine, which can be seen. The tea tastes wonderful.

We absolutely loved our experience at Glenloch Tea Estate. The tea tour was truly unforgettable, thanks to our knowledgeable guide who explained every step of tea-making with so much detail and passion. It was fascinating to see the skill, time, and dedication that go into producing each cup of tea. A highlight was dressing up in traditional tea-picking attire and trying to fill a basket ourselves—it was much harder than it looked but so much fun! And the Golden Flush tea we tried? Simply elite. We’re hooked and will only be drinking this from now on!

Really interesting tour of the factory to see how Tea is made. Super friendly staff whose English was perfect making it a very engaging tour for us. Great to sample the different teas and purchase some too. Lovely to get the opportunity to pick some tea too

Our Guide arranged a visit to this factory because we wanted to discover the Ceylon tea plantations. Delighted by our visit: nights visited the factory and the processes, tasted the different teas made and even learned how to pick. Very rewarding. Our hostess was charming. We also bought some boxes of good teas as a souvenir ❤️

We were part of a group and had a very interesting visit around the Glenloch estate & factory. Our guide was very knowledgable and gave us an interesting & informative tour of the factory which was very detailed. We visited the plantation where we picked some leaves. A great experience. The tea tasting experience was enjoyable and there was no rush. We visited the boutique which is quite expensive but again, any purchases were our own choice. An experience worth repeating.
We got a nice tour on the plantage en fabric with friendly staff. Not pushy at all to buy anything. It's worth seeing also with kids.

The tour around the factory was fantastic. The tour guide was very knowledgeable and answered all of our questions. We tasted several types of tea afterwards and had some lovely cake. Whilst the shop was filled with many types of tea and beautiful tins, it was disappointing to find out that they were much more expensive than a supermarket. We thought buying directly from the factory was a cost efficient option. You can buy these tins from supermarkets as a hugely discounted rate.

Glenloch Tea Factory offers an interesting tour of tea production, from cultivation to drying and packing. The tour is FREE and provides a great opportunity to learn about Sri Lanka's tea industry. The factory also has a gift shop where visitors can purchase tea. It would have been great to have gift box sets to bring to Friends & Family back home. The sets they have are BIG (= expensive) or do not have Glenloch packaging (it looks like tea box bought from any supermarket... no gift worthy)

Came here with Mercury holidays as part of our tour of Sri Lanka. It was a Monday so one of the production lines wasn’t working. No problem, our lady guide was very precise in her explanation of how they produce tea, we had a go at “ picking” , had a taste and obligatory stop at the shop! My only complaint per say would be the shop could do with smaller  “gift” boxes of tea, we did find a couple of small ones, but I like to buy for gifts and they were still a little big for my liking. Enjoyed the tour.

The visit is very informative, despite the coldness of our hostess A visit to the store is essential, but there, the staff is really anti-commercial. You are there to buy and not to ask questions!! The saleswoman gives us a dented box and never wanted to change it, claiming that there were no more

The driver insisted to bring us here, so we gave this a chance. We tried 3 teas, which I can only describe as ranging from cardboard to floor dust flavour notes. I asked some questions about tea, none of which they were able to answer, for example question ‘what variety of white tea is this?’ Answer ‘white tea’. Thank you. At the end they force you to go the shop and then they get very pushy and annoying. Unsurprisingly one then learns that their workers are very poorly paid which raises all sorts of ethical questions. Absolutely avoid.

My wife and I are Sri Lankan and a colleague/friend of ours visited Sri Lanka while we were there, so we took him to see Glenloch.  He got a tour of the factory and the nice lady showed him the process the tea goes through after it’s plucked to the point it is packaged.  He also was able to try tea plucking.  This is a very nice place to visit and learn about Ceylon tea. They also allow you to taste many types of tea.  They have the largest selection of teas for purchase that I’ve ever seen in one location in Sri Lanka.  I really liked their tea shop because in one place we could purchase every type of tea we wanted.  I will bring many of our friends who are visiting from the USA to see Glenloch. We had a good time here.

Stopped here on a tour of inland Sri Lanka and was given a very comprehensive of the tea process from plantation, picking the leaves through to drying and grading te various teas. We then had a tasting experience and the opportunity to purchase some of their products in the shop. Very interesting place with super helpful and knowledgable staff and certainly worth a visit if passing by. This is just one of many different plantations / factories and would imagine they're much of a muchness but if you happen to pass this estate and you've not visited another than drop in and learn all about how tea ends up in your mug.

I visited Glenloch Tea Factory. It was a good experience to understand how tea is manufactured. Factory Engineer and Supervisor Mrs. Jeevani has demonstrated the complete tea manufacturing process excellently. From welcoming to explaining process and equipments and tea products with sample tastes, it was a wonderful experience. Thank you very much to all the staff!!
Very informative visit ladies who show you around are lovely.. free tea tasting.. free entry.. tea shop is lovely. & a go at tea picking with the tea ladies

It was super interesting to get an insight into the making of tee! Our guide Ms. Devika was amazing she answered all of our questions and explained everything very well we couldn’t have had a better guide! She also spoke very good English as well as German which was very helpful :) Overall a very nice place to stop for a visits if you’re interested in Tee you can taste different tees as well !
Interesting visit, we were able to taste different teas. The staff speaks French which made it easier to understand the explanations. The store offers all varieties of teas produced on site.

Lovely spot, but it might depend which guide you get at this place. Mine was smiley and pleasant but rushed me through the tea factory, hardly explained anything, had no opportunity to pick tea, and was overly eager to "help" me purchase tea in the shop. I had to speak quite firmly to her to get her to back off. Also, why doesn't anyone mention the tea pickers themselves? They are the backbone of the industry, as I understand it. Generally low income Tamil women. The guide acted as though they didn't exist and failed to point out the tip box in the factory for the pickers. But she was certainly angling for her own tip. I'd try another place next time.

Since we arrived all employees were very nice and polite. The rooms were very big and bed very comfortable, also with a nice view on tea hills. In the morning after breakfast we visited the tea factory and tea plantation. Ms. Shiva guided us trough it with a perfect and detailed explanation and after she showed us how to take and select the right leaves in order to have the perfect tea. After a tea tasting we could buy some of their delicious teas. Thank you very much for this experience! A special thanks to Ms. Shiva and all the hotel employees.

We had an amazing stay in GLENLOCH we book online and they provided a very nice accommodation, very clean and the staff was super kind. The tea experience and factory was a pleasant experience thanks to Shiva that explained us every single step. We bought some tea directly from their shop and I can not wait to taste it. We will be back for sure. Thank you guys for this experience I’ll hope to be back soon.

We've chosen this place because they have a hotel, and a tour around the tea factory was included in the price of stay. The guide explained all stages of tea making, a very kind lady who was eager to answer questions. We also tried plucking tea and tasted their tea. Delicious, overall, the factory is definitely worth visiting. You may also have a tour in the French language. Pretty convenient location, especially if you're hiking along Pekoe trail and are looking for a place to spend the night at. Also, Ramboda waterfall is just in 10 minutes from here by bus. Отличная фабрика чая с отелем. В ценник вошла экскурсия по фабрике на английском языке, визит на плантацию с возможностью пособирать чай, дегустация чая и номер в отеле с завтраком. Можно бронировать на букинге. Мы очень довольны, отличное расположение, если вы идёте по маршруту Pekoe Trail. Также отсюда можно добраться на автобусе до водопада Рамбода за 10 минут.

This plantation and factory is worth visiting. It is not overly commercial and still has much of the original machinery.  As an avid tea drinker I learnt a lot, especially about tea dust. The ladies who looked after us were warm, friendly and a little wicked, in a nice way. A tip: there is no picking on Sunday thus the machinery does not operate on Monday. That is when the factory is cleaned.

Very interesting visit .  We were welcomed and shown around by Sasi .  She told us about the history of the tea factory and plantation .  She also informed us of the different types of tea and process of making and plucking  the tea too.  Before trying the differing types.  A good experience

Second Tea Factory visit and arguably the better one, our guide was superb, very informative, showed us all around and explained very well the different processes. We sampled the different teas in their tea shop and purchased some of the blends to take home. We were also put to work picking tea on their plantation which was an experience - I’m not very good!

Nice tea factory. We came in the evening, stayed in a hotel right on the factory. In the morning right after breakfast we had very interesting excursion on factory and tea plants with guide Shiwa. She told us a story about a factory, tea history, showed us all the technological process of tea factoring, explained a difference between white, green and black tea, all the black tea types and qualities and many other interesting things about tea, people, who produce it, about Sri-Lanka and  all around.
Lovely tour guide Gung and smashing teas to taste afterwards. And a very beautiful setting. Definitely worth stopping by.
Tea color and taste is very bad after adding a spoonful of Milk. That is why they don't keep even milk powder at the tasting facility.
Worst experience. Solid marketing but terrible results back home. Red Label is much more better than this Glenloch. One must ask for tasting after adding a bit of milk.
Subhashini, Explained very well stage by stage which was exemplary.  We recommend this place honestly. Thanks, Vettri
Priya gave us a lovely tour of the tea factory. Finishing off with a tea tasting at the beautiful terrace with a view over the plantations. Thanks a lot.

This is such a beautiful tea plantation. We were guided round the factory and explained the process by Divya. Divya then took us to taste the tea and pick tea in the plantations ourselves. Excellent service, brilliant experience and delicious tea.

A must stop on the way to Ella. The tour is completely free, with samples of tea at the end. We had the amazing Divya give us the tour. Her English was impeccable and she was so knowledgeable, having worked there for 10 years! Their tea is so delicious, we couldn't resist buying some in the lovely shop at the end.

We received a fun tour at the tea plantation where we picked some tea and saw how it was processed in the factory. Afterwards we had a sampling of the various tea blends. They have a nice tea shop where you can buy the Tea that you liked.

Our driver recommended the place. We first had a short tour around the factory then we went to the plantation, where we tried to pick the tea leaves on our own. Afterwards we had a brief tea tasting and then we could shop in the local store. We liked the tea with guava and sour sop, so the store has prepared for us a few extra cans.
I dear friend visited Sri Lanka and brought back a tin of Glenloch orange pekoe Best brightest flavourI have found in a lifetime of tea sampling

A short but informative trip round this small tea factory. Some of the machinery processing the tea was very old (not operational when we visited) An opportunity to learn about the variety of teas and how they are produced. A good taster session. We bought a load and I am still enjoying it. Many thanks.
An informative visit to a tea factory which explained the production process from picking to the tea cup. Informative but short. You do get a pleasant cup of tea however at the end.

We had bad experience at Store Field Tea Factory with pushy sales girl and guide who spoke like bullet train speed. Comparatively, the experience here was relatively better. Guide spoke with reasonable speed and informative yet not too much information overload. We got to experience the tea plucker’s hardship, using the rattan basket, holding with a strap over the forehead. Then, we proceed to the cafe for tea tasting. There were cakes and chocolates available for sales while tasting the tea. We purchased a packet of tea that cost LKR2,000 as souvenirs which was not really cheap. Good thing is that the guide wasn’t as pushy as the previous tea factory we visited at Store Field Tea Factory. There are also shop selling other souvenirs, soap , perfumes and toiletries products, etc. We told our driver that this would be our last tea factory to visit since we are not really a tea connoisseur who is particular about the tea quality. Having said that, visit 1 or 2 tea factory is a must in Sri Lanka especially within Nuwara Eliya region since Ceylon (old name for Sri Lanka) Tea is one of the world famous tea.

As a chauffeur guide it is us who recommend the guest/ tourist about a hotel or restuarant for lunch. Yesterday I had to take my guests to Glenloch for lunch and i am seriously disappointed the way they treated us. Is it fair to charge for guides meal as we take the guest for the restuarant ? The staff is so rude saying that the guest had only one portion meal therefore i had to pay for guide meal. This will be the first and last time we will take a guest for your restuarant. Hereafter will not recommend glenloch for anyone. For your kind information this message will be forwarded to all tourist guide groups and relavant tourism companies as well. Glen lodge do not forget that you gain your business mostly through our (guides)  recommendations.

My wife and I enjoyed this free tour of the Tea factory.  Our tour guide was very knowledgeable and we were shown how the tea leaves were brought into the factory and allowed to dry out.  There were many aspects of the tea leaves going through the various machinery.  We were also shown how the tea leaves were graded and packed.  Finally, we bought some tea and a lovely tea pot in the shop which were reasonably priced.

Given the importance of tea in Sri Lanka it felt right to have a look around a tea factory. It is reasonably interesting and they offer a 'free' tour but we did feel quite pushed to buy something in the shop and our guide hung close to us while we were browsing. Not the best part of our trip but a worth a visit to do something different, but don't go out of my way to go there.
Big factory. Good tea. Nice terrace. But guide was so... not very interesting. Plus they had some floor renovation so there was glue smell all over the place
Very interesting and cognitively ☝🏻 We saw the process of working with tea. We walked near tea plantation , tried different tipes of tea. Very cool 😎

Fairly attractive premises externally and a nice balcony area to sit and sample the various teas produced on the estate while listening to a commentary on their origins and production. Then it as off to the factory where the guide took us through the various stages from picking, drying, fermenting, etc. Interesting talk but difficult to hear with the noise of the machinery. No noise reduction earmuffs being worn or evident anywhere. From there we progressed to the shop where the finished product in all it's varieties awaited us in assorted packets, containers, tins, presentation boxes, etc. I enjoyed the tastings when we arrived but considered the priced product way higher than I expected and did not make a purchase despite the best endeavors and entreaties of the fashionable sales ladies.  Interesting visit and we left with a greater appreciation of the conditions that are experienced by the workforce before our favourite brands reach the shelves.

We went when they were about to shut, but even then they took us around and explained to us in detail, what is the process of tea making.Very knowledgeable got to taste the various teas. overall very interesting.

We had a fabulous tour at this working tea factory. Our guide was extremely knowledgeable and it was fascinating to see how tea is processed and hear how the process has evolved over time. The tea tasting at the end of the tour was a nice way to end, and they allowed us to try the more expensive teas at no cost. We also ate lunch here which was tasty and well priced. We didn't feel any pressure to purchase in the shop, although we did, however they listened to what we wanted and our budget and showed us only that. Highly recommend a visit.

We must have had a bad tour guide, because everyone else seems to have had a good experience here. Our tour guide spent less than 10 minutes with us. She rushed us through the processing rooms, didn't speak loud enough to hear her over the machinery and only seemed interested in getting us into the gift shop -- and it wasn't even a busy day! This would have been an ideal location for a full tour. We would have loved to walk through the fields to see the workers picking the tea, and to take the time to understand how the tea is processed. But we learned very little with our whirlwind tour. It was nice to have a complimentary cup of tea at the end of the tour, however. We had such wonderful experiences all over Sri Lanka. The locals could not be more accommodating and friendly. This was the only sour note in our entire visit to this lovely, welcoming country. Perhaps the tour guide was just having a bad day...
We have visited several tea factories. This one may not have the most informative guided tours but they sell organic tea. I don’t mind paying some Rupees more for superior quality.
Glenloch tea tree plantation was a lovely and  peaceful. The scenic view was  breathtaking, lush and full of tea plants and other greenery.

We were on the road from Kandy to Nuwara Eliya and took an hour to stop at the Glenloch Tea Factory. We were invited to pick tea leaves in the fields and so began our first lessons in the art of tea making. So many things to learn but our guide Ganga, made our tour really enjoyable. We then entered the main processing part of the tour, learning how the tea leaves are dried, ground, filtered and crushed before being roasted. The kids and adults had a great experience, finished off by tea tasting. The atmosphere was relaxed and there was no pressure to purchase along the way...however by the time we had finished everyone wanted to buy some tea. Thanks again to Ganga for making the tour so much fun.

Unplanned visit. we were short on time for going towards nuwara eliya from kandy. I dont drink tea in fact never tasted. Our driver recommended so decided to take a small stop. Interesting and informative tour and follow up with a free cup of tea (if you like to). We ended up buying lot of tea for family and friends :)

An excellent tour, well organised and led by a lovely guide who explained the processes well. Finished with tea tastings and a visit to the shop, but we did not feel pressured to buy. (but we did buy several boxes!)

We decided to stop at Glenloch for our tea experience rather than the many other processers around Nuwara Eliya as photos of the factory are permitted, as well as due to the fact it was on the way to the town from Kandy. We arrived to be welcomed by a member of staff who would take us around the factory. Tours are free but visitors are invited to give tips at the end which are distrubuted among all staff. We started our tour seeing the picked leaves being sorted. You are then taken through the whole processing process, from drying, through to cutting, to packing. It was a fascinating insight into a product that so many people enjoy. None of it is staged (although there is some now redundant equipment around to help explain how things were done before some parts of the process were mechanised) so you are seeing tea which well end up in your tea back home being processed. At the end of the tour you are invited to try some of the teas and of course purchase some if you wish.  You can also wander around outside and see people picking tea. Definitely worth a stop if you are travelling between Kandy and Nuwara Eliya: its a good way to stretch the legs.

I quite liked the visit to Glenloch Tea Factory where I gathered so much more than just information on Tea leaves. It was quite an experience. Make sure when u visit them there is no power cut or else you wont get to see the working factory model. They even give you to taste different flavour's of tea. I loved the Vanilla one highly recommended for people who prefer black tea.

Quite informative tour, demonstrating how tea is produced.  It was quite short and curt and lacked real detail.  The opportunity to try tea picking was good.  Tasting was just of one brew - which was disappointing.  The shop had a decent range of products available

We are independent travelers and decided to try this plantation to break up our trip between Kandy and NUwara Eliya. It turned out to be a good choice as it was  quite a good tour we were guided through by an English speaking guide. This tour is free of charge. There is a free tasting of all the different types of tea varieties.  There is a sales room and they also sell fine chocolates. Well worth a visit.

We visited as part of a Tour group en route from Kandy to the Hill Country. We did the Factory tour with full process explanations from an English speaking employee. Then a tasting experience and on to the shop, with innumerable tea offerings. Good stop off.

A big drawback for us was that it was the “Full-Moon” holiday and the workers were not in the fields or in the factory.  The tour still showed the tea drying and where the workers would be. We had a tea tasting. Be sure to ask for milk and sugar if you want it, because it is not automatically offered. It is easy to spend lots of money on tea to take home.  Caveat Emptor

This tea factory makes a great pit-stop when travelling between Kandy and Ella. We arrived just as a coach tour was leaving and although crowded we had an English speaking guide to ourselves. The tour took us through the full sequence of preparing tea and we learnt about the difference between the varieties ( Strong, Pekoe, Green  etc.)  The restrooms were clean. the tour ended with a tasting of several varieties of teas, after which we bought some for ourselves and as gifts for friends. The only downside was that  Livingston Harvest Green Tea with Raspberry and Strawberry we brought home  expecting a tasty fruit tea turned out to be a coarse green tea with no additives that is undrinkable. It tasted and looked like a cabbage leaf tea...not at all what is to be expected of any sri lankan tea.

As an avid tea drinker,a visit to a major factory was always on the cards. The guided tour of the factory was conducted at a reasonably slow pace, with full descriptions of all the processes. The guide spoke very good English and took her time without hurrying us along. All questions were answered clearly so we understood everything. At the end, we were all treated to a tea tasting - different types of tea - at a slow pace. There is also a well-stocked gift shop (expected), but there was absolutely no pressure at all to buy anything - well done! Importantly, the on-site toilets have been really well refurbished much to everyone's surprise - another well done! So, to sum up - this is well worth the effort to visit.

I love tea, so I was always going to visit A tea factory.  I understand they're all pretty much of a muchness, all similarly styled from the colonial days of past.  The walk around with an attractive and good English speaking female talked us through the tea making process from the leaf picking to the sorting, drying, crushing, dividing, bagging of the leaves. All looks archaic but it seems to do the trick and they produce and export an enormous quantity per day, so very impressive.  You then get a taste of 3 teas, black, green & white - all good then you can buy loose or bags.  I must say we did buy some green tea and now home can taste the difference to what I've bought in supermarkets.  What they don't show you are the fields and pickers, but you do have the benefit of seeing these lush fields on steep hills on the route into the plantations.  Looks like incredibly hard work but the Sri Lankan people are generous with their smiles so go ahead and visit if you have time.

We stopped here to visit the tea factory and the plantation. The tea pickers demonstrated their skills and the factory workers the process of producing tea. This was followed by a tea tasting session of various strengths and types before visiting the onsite shop.

We had a great tour of the tea factory and the guide showed us and told us of each process, a tea picking competition was held after the tour with a box of tea as a prize. we sampled the tea afterwards. well worth the visit enjoyed our time here and there was a well stocked shop to browse and buy tea too.

Visited here on Jan 22nd,2019. This Ceylon tea factory uses equipment from India & Japan to process tea. You can also climb the tea plantation and photo op with a tea picking basket. An employee explained us the process and lead us through the factory and you can also shop for different flavors of tea in the shop like Orange-grapefruit,black earl grey, cherry & mangoosteen etc. Sample tea drink also served here. Eatery is also attached for pastry/snacks.

As tea lovers we were looking forward to a few hours at Glenloch and we weren’t disappointed. Our guide was very knowledgable and explained the whole process of the tea manufacturing from start to finish. We were given a tour throughput the factory, took photo’s and asked questions. It was fascinating to see and so incredible what goes into it all. We got a chance to puck some tea leaves which was great fun! Afterwards we got to try some of the different varieties and purchase some from their well stocked shop. Brilliant tour and highly recommend.

The factory offers a SHORT tour on their grounds where they will show you the tree plants. You are likely to meet Tamil ladies (who pluck an average 30kg of tea leaves per day)  along the way, who will offer to pose with you for a photo for some money (50-100rs should be sufficient "reward") Factory tour shows you the traditional and modern way of tea making , and at the end you'll be offered black tea with some cookies in their shop where you can then buy some tea. TIP: Try the coconut sweetener & cookie with your tea, its a local replacement for sugar ;)

We made a brief stop here to visit the tea factory. The staff explained the process of tea manufacturing and then we were taken to there cafe for tasting tea. You can also buy different types of tea to take back home. This place has nice views of the valley.

We dropped into Glenloch for a quick look at tea production and some lunch.  We noticed other visitors receiving guided tours but nobody approached us so we just took a look around ourselves.  It's a bit like stepping back in time for anyone who works in modern manufacturing with a lot of manual labour interspersed with some very old machines. Lunch was quite good although our waiter didn't seem all that interested in serving us.  I recommend the Nasi Goreng. We bought some tea from the extensive range in their tourist shop which is worth a visit as you can smell and/or taste most of the teas available.

This was scheduled by our guide. The tour was well done and explained thoroughly. Different parts of tea leaf and stem create different tasting teas. This was informative. Afterwards offered free samples to taste in beautiful lounge area and  onto to gift shop to purchase. I drink a lot of tea and I wasn’t blown away by taste of tea although we liked the white and silver tea and purchased. I noticed our guide received free tea. There are many tea factories in this area. I don’t know why guide picked this particular place.
We had an interest and informative tour of the tea factory followed by a tea tasting and the opportunity to buy some tea from the gift shop. Good activity for all ages.

We made a brief stop at the Glenloch Tea Factory as part of our visit to the Nuwara Eliya tea highlands. We had a very informative tour and explanation of the tea production process, and saw some interesting old machinery from the colonial days still in use! The different types and gradings of tea were explained (i now know exactly what is meant by broken orange pekoe) and then we sat down to taste some free samples (NB: cake costs extra). Afterwards, it was on to the gift shop which sold the finished product at reasonable prices. As I had always suspected (and the visit confirmed) the tea we use in the West in our teabags really is called "dust"!....

A quick and free tour it was good to see and learn more about the tea and different types and sizes giving different flavours. Free tea tasting and cup of tea.  The tea shop is how they make their money but it was not madly over priced and did not feel pressured. The views are worth the stop alone.

When you do the must-visit tea factory tour I guess it depends a lot on the guide. Our guide was pleasant and knowledgeable and answered our questions competently and politely.This factory has some quite old machinery which is fascinating in its own right.You can also visit the plantation itself but we seemed to be left alone to do that if we wished. You are given five varieties of tea to taste, which was served with a smile and was nicely hot. Then of course the shop - and what seemed expensive packets of tea. But we did follow the notice saying no tips - which is probably the only one you will see in Sri Lanka!
Our driver made a stop here on the our way up to our hotel. enjoyed good tea. staff were informative. Made some purchases of green and black tea. enjoying it.

We were taken around the factory, and the whole process explained to us. Our guide was knowledgeable and answered our questions, but rather unenthusiastic. He whisked us past the sign which said "Do not give tips", and hovered pointedly at the end, as we were trying the different teas. (We resisted). There is a large shop, but as soon as you show any interest the sales lady is unrelenting, so browsing is difficult.

Visiting a tea factory is a must when visiting SriLanka.   The amazing fresh tea smell permeates the air, and the landscape of Nuwara Eliya is beautiful.   Glenloch is no exception. Our guide to the tea factory spouted many dodgy facts about tea.  For example, she seemed to think black tea was high in vitamin C and had more vitamin C than green tea.   She did not know what fermentation or oxidation were.  When I asked questions to clarify her knowledge, she hit back by asking my travel partner whether I could understand English. Ouch!  She then treated me like a retard who couldn't understand what she was saying, which was totally fine with me, because I knew she didn't know even the basics of the tea making process.   I have attached a picture of the dodgy guide.   Surely it takes only 10minutes of reading Wikipedia to pass some basic facts on and she couldn't even do that. I've attached a pic of the guide. We didn't get a tour of the plantation outside.  We were told we could wander down the path/road to take a better look outside.  We weren't allowed to walk on the plantation slopes as a safety precaution. Once inside, we tasted just one type of tea. It was OK.   The shop was a bit overpriced.  I bought BOP tea in the cheapest packaging, it was 1000rupees. No discounts, no haggling.   Our driver was pretty happy because he got some free tea from the ladies there once we had made our purchases.  I think drivers who bring visitors to Glenloch obviously get perks which depend on how much their visitors spend -  that's enough incentive for them to choose this tea factory over others.  The tea itself tastes great.   Heaps better than the Dilmah you get in Australia. In this factory, the same tea gets packaged as different brands.  The price point is just determined by how fancy the brand is, which is mainly comes down to how beautiful the packaging is.   So you might as well buy the no frills packaging.

Tour delivered in a speedy and robotic fashion - was difficult to understand and then man marked in the shop and felt pressured to purchase something, weren’t able to browse at own pace. Tea tasting was good though.

Factory guide girls are really friendly you can find a guide who can speak your language. They explain it very well. And also tea here is upto the standard. You can taste different types of tea free of charge. I take my clients to this place as the first stop on the way to Nuwara eliya from Kandy.

This short your was amazing ! The guide was incredible and taking us through the factory was an eye opener ! The shop was a little expensive to be fair but I cannot deny the Sri Lankan people trying to make a little money I’ve just arrived home and had my first cup of tea of the Royal- wow- seriously wow ! Fresh tea and first class quality- if you could buy this tea as fresh and as beautiful as it is you’d do it all day everyday- wish I had not been so frugal and bought more not just for ourselves but to share with friends.’great tour and well worth the stop by. Thank you for your hospitality expertly included in our itinerary by Blue  Lanka Tours and our. Guide Mr Prakash Keerthy

We liked the tour very much and was interesting to see how tea is being made. At the end you go through a shop. We wanted to buy white tea and we were told that it is not possible to buy it at the supermarket or local shop other than this shop. This was not true. We paid 4 time the cost in the supermarket!

Having been driven up into the highlands of sri lanka by ranjan we stopped at glenloch .this is where there are more than just black and green tea silver and gold are now added to the list.all are made from the top leaves silver and gold are from the youngest and smallest leaves and along with green are not fermemted Tea came to sri lanka when a scots man borrowed some tea plants from china the rest is history

Stopped here and had a tour of the factory. Quite interesting particularily some of the victorian machinery still being used but the tour is brief. Then it is into the cafe and shop where you can try a varirty of teas and purchase different teas and souvenirs. Typical tourist type place.

Visited this factory as part of a tour group and it was very interesting. (Just would have been better if our group of 18 had been split into 2 smaller groups so it was easier to hear). After the tour got the opportunity to test the various teas before looking round the shop. There was a nice handmade chocolate counter - a few free samples might have encouraged people to buy as they looked delicious. Lovely views from the car park
This tour was recomended by our driver but the tour itself was perfunctory, around 10 minutes and they seemed more keen to get us into the shop. The guide herself did not seem overly interested.

We were recommended by our driver ( whose mother is a tea leaf picker)who we have for the week.its a working tea factory,our guide explained the process involved from tree to teacup and we found it fascinating.We both enjoy working factory experiences and the guide was fine.At the end we went into the shop and had some tea buying some rather nice chocolates to have with our teas -I don’t normally drink the stuff!

Was super excited to see a tea factory but the guide we had was HORRENDOUS. First we had to stand and wait for 20 minutes for a guide. They gave us one guide who walked away two minutes later with no word. They put us in another group and that group said they had just finished the tour wtf? Finally they put us with this woman who was the WORST. She was going a mile a minute, SCREAMING at us to hurry, grabbing me up the stairs and her body was all over me. It was so bizarre. A woman asked her to slow down but she refused. Tried to get my husband to smell tea and went so fast she stuck the entire bowl of tea into his nose!!!!! We spent more time waiting for the tour than the actual tour. She then followed me the entire way around the over priced gift shop hassling me nonstop. She should find a different job, this is not for her!!!

We visited the tea factory in August.  The whole tour in my opinion was rushed , we didn't get any time to ask the guide any questions about the tea making process.  We were hurriedly rushed outside to try the tea which was nice (thinking this was the tea that we would eventually end up buying from their shop).  We finished our tea and were told we could purchase the tea from the shop.  The shop was overcrowded very poor customer service,  the staff did not explain fully when we asked about a particular tea .  We eventually did buy 5 packets of their flavoured tea.     Back home we tried the cardamom tea, to our disappointment the tea was flavourless very very weak ( I left my teabag in my mug for an hour) no flavour and tasted like water .  Waste of money would not recommend going there ever.
Well organized and informative. Our guide was well informed, friendly and helpful. If you're a tea drinker/lover I'd definitely recommend a visit

Having spent 4 days in the beautiful Ella and Nuwara Eliya areas we were disappointed by this factory tour. Short and non motivational followed by pressure to buy what we discovered  later was “expensive” tea.

The lady showing us around was nice, and the factory itself is cool. The tour is free, but the tour itself lasts maybe 10 minutes, afterwards they rush you to the shop where they walk after you like hawks pressuring you to buy something. There was variety of tea, with nice packaging, but it was only later (after visiting other factories) we realised that it was overpriced! Wish a bought my tea elsewhere. Afterwards we went to Damro tea factory, which had professional staff and a beautiful place with awesome view to drink tea, I'd recommend that place instead

The tour of the tea factory was very interesting with incredible smells. Refreshingly, we weren’t pestered or rushed into the shop at the end as one usually is at the end of such tours. Even so, the shop was very busy as the prices are good and the quality of the tea is high. They also offer free tastings of the different teas they make.

Not only are the views breathtakingly beautiful, but the tea served here was delicious! Our guide took us around the factory and allowed us time to peruse before moving on to the next section. Our guide spoke excellent English and answered any questions we had. After the tour, we were served complimentary tea of each variety that the factory sold. My personal favourite being the white silver tip tea. While we were tasting our guide explained the health benefits if each. On site they had a chocoletier stand, and these chocolates were also delicious. Although compared to most places you visit in Sri Lanka, the tea that they sold was more expensive than any where else we had visited. The price is 100% worth it! my partner and I purchased both the golden flush, BOPF, BOP and silver tip tea, and all are fantastic. Tea picking! Once we had finished in the tea factory's resturaunt, we had an opportunity to pick tea from one of the Glenloch tea gardens. All in all a very enjoyable experience and if i were ever in Sri Lanka again I would definitely re-visit.

Close look at how world most popular drink is made from Leaf to cup Amazing view of tea mountains Free tea served for guest Average cold cosy climate , Has tea shop even with outlet of noritake Gift shop for taking back home some pure Ceylon tea

Of all the tea estates to visit do not choose this one. Our driver insisted we come here because it is one of the estates that is 100% Sri Lankan owned. Whilst I wanted to support local business the way we were treated here was disappointing. The lady provided a very rushed tour, she had no expression on her face and often yawned. When we asked any questions she was reluctant to answer. Of course at the end she wanted her tip and when we were browsing the shop she suddenly became interested in helping us (perhaps she gets a commission). We were so excited to visit this beautiful part of Sri Lanka but being treated like we were just $$ took the pleasure out of our experience. I have heard other estates provide more customer service training to their staff and might be better to visit. I hope the owners of the Glenloch estate read this and review their service levels.

The tour was short and informative, and the friendly staff promptly provided tea of all sorts for tasting. There are plenty of places to buy your Sri Lankan tea, but when you buy it from here you know it directly benefits the factory workers.

Called here as part of our trip around Sri Lanka and to say we were disappointed would be an understatement. We asked to use toilets before we started but guide just kept going and started tour. She did speak good English but only that we had been to tea museum in Kandy we would not have a clue as she rushed through tour and did not really give time to take photos or ask questions. Mind you had no problem standing next to us while we had our cup of tea waiting for tip(that never came). After our driver brought us to Dromore which was fantastic experience compared. Be careful what factory visited as not all the same!

Nice visit at Glenloch tea factory. We had a english speaking guide who showed us the tea factory. She told us all about the process. We could ask questions and she gave us good answers. Afterwards we got to taste black, white, green tea. Nice store where you could buy tea. Good experience!

Apparently one of the few tea factories that let you take photos. We really enjoyed our experience with our informative guide - learning about the processing of tea. We watched it being dried, sorted, roasted and packaged. We then got to try a number of types... our favourites were the OP and white tea. Chocolates are delicious and a great accompaniment to the tea. I suggest giving lunch a miss though. It was very average for a high price for Sri Lanka.

Nice place. will had a a great tour. show and explain everything in detail about Tea making process. from plant to cup of tea. It was really interesting to see the process from beginning to end. Thanks

We had visited similar places in India and China but still enjoyed our tour of Glenloch.  We had a lovely guide who explained the whole process and at the end enjoyed a tasting of a couple of the teas. Finally, we were allowed to do a bit of tea picking, touristy yes but still good fun.

Called in here for the factory tour and was amazed at how genuinely historically it has been kept. Very noisy so it was difficult to hear what the charming guide was saying but even so very worthwhile. Nice cup of tea at the end and no pressure to buy any products.

An excellent tea factory tour that showed us the art of how high quality Sri Lankan tea was made and furthermore there was an classy tea center with a cosy cafe overlooking the entire tea Fields. Would definitely recommend!

You get to see the journey of the famed Ceylon tea from the field to your cup. The guide shows you all the processes involved and also the various types of tea that is made. At the end of the tour you get to taste each variety of tea before making a purchase( optional)

Glenloch is certainly worth a visit. We had a a great tour which showed us exactly how the leaf is turned into a lovely cup of tea. It also explained how different kinds of tea are made. After the tour we headed down to try four different types of tea, each of which were delicious. Before leaving we made sure we purchased some tea, however I must add that we were not pressured into doing so. Breathtaking views of the surrounding hills and a lovely cuppa. What more could you want.

We had an amazing time, all thanks to Priya. She was fantastic from the start and took her time to show us and explain everything in detail. We took a tour around the factory, met some of the workers and then tried some complimentary tea. We then went out into the fields, where there were stunning views and Priya showed us how tea pickers normally work. It really made us understand how hard this job is and connected the dots for us regarding the whole process -from plant to cup of tea. It was important for us to see and will make us even more aware when we buy tea in the UK. Glenloch is situated in a breathtaking location but we would not have enjoyed it without our event excellent guide Priya

I really enjoyed the visit to this tea factory. It was really interesting to see the process from beginning to end. This is still a thriving and active tea factory. Very informative and great to see the various stages of production. Enjoyed the smells too. Good tasting experience at the end and of course, we bought some!

From the field to the cup Glenloch Tea Factory is worth a visit. So much more to tea than what you’re drinking. We joined tea pluckers in the field.  There is an art in picking the leaves.  We had the baskets balanced on our back with rope tethered to our head to put the picked leaves in. Then the next step was to take the picked leaves to the factory for processing. Different fields for growing different teas. People attending this event then get a chance to taste the different teas.  I bought a couple of tins of The Royal Tea!  Yes the Royal family purchase this tea from Glenloch. We spent about 2hrs here on our road trip with Pledge Holidays Sri Lanka.

It was interesting to see the production process of tea making right from the drying of tea leaves, to processing, cleaning and packaging. The guide patiently attended to our queries. We also got to sample some brewed tea along with delicious vanilla cakes. There’s an in house shop that helps you to stock up on different varieties of teas which is a must buy when visiting Sri Lanka. Prices are very reasonable. The surroundings are scenic and would appeal to avid photographers. The icing on the cake is that you can pose in and play act the tea leaves picking experience, which makes for a great photo-op.

We had earlier on visited a tea museum in a former tea factory so it was very interesting to visit an active tea factory to see the different processes and all the different kinds of tea made from the same plant. We had a free cup of tea and also had the chance to taste and compare green tea, white tea and brown tea. (We can recommend the brownie cake in the cafe, it didn’t look as fancy as the other cakes in the display but it had a good taste)

Along the winding drive through the mountains and tea plantations, we stopped at Glenloch Tea Factory. It was really interesting and our guide was knowledgeable and to the point which we liked. After the tour we enjoyed a cup of tea on the balcony and took in the beautiful views before hitting the road again.

Most tea factories have become just for tourists and are there for show, however Glenloch was different. This factory was a lot less busy, so the guide we had didn’t need to rush us through. We was able to see all the staff at work and also were able to take pictures (most of the factories don’t allow this.) It was fascinating to see the process of tea making! At the end we was able to taste 5 different types of tea with gorgeous views of the tea fields. What’s best is all of this is free! There’s a huge selection of teas to buy afterwards, some that come in beautiful wodden boxes, which make great gifts! Would recommend this trip to any tea lover!

Most of the bags are either split or they split when stirring in the cup. You end up with a heap of tea leaf bits at the bottom of your cuppa. A complete waste of money and so disappointing after an enjoyable tour.

On our trip around Sri Lanka we stop among many places here, our guide set us up with a guide a the factory that went trough all the steps of tea making. It was really interesting, and more so if we actually could hear what she said all the time. The noice was a bit to load as the tour was in the actual factory. But maybe she could have spoken up a bit, we had to stay really close and pay attention to hear the main parts at least. After we tasted the different teas and bought quite much to family and friends.

We did not stay at the hotel but did visit the Glenloch Tea Factory en route to Kandy.  The tour was rushed and missed out half the processes.  The sole aim appeared to get us into the showroom and sell us overpriced tea and chocolates.  There must be better tea factories to visit!

This was an interesting view of how tea is made, and it was free! Our guide was very good, we were tagged onto a large group who kept taking ages to move on. After tour got our samples of the different types of tea. Restaurant was nice with a beautiful view. Was slightly pressured by not buying something, which we didn’t. Shop very busy and small.

An attractive young woman took us and an Italian couple round the factory. She had clearly repeated the same information many times over and seemed somewhat stopped in her tracks when we showed interest and asked questions. She appeared eager to get us through to the end and give us a cup of tea, before escorting us through to the shop, where we were clearly expected to buy some tea. In our opinion the prices were extortionate and we left without purchasing. The young lady appeared very disappointed. Not clear if she has to rely on the sales that are made. Our driver who chose to take us here rather than a factory that I asked to go to, was also very clearly upset that we didn't buy and tried (in vain) to persuade us to go back in and buy some!

I recommend this stop, the tour is educational and unlike many tea tours this one you get right up close to the driers, sorters, etc. It certainly opens your eyes as to long the proceeds needed to bring is all our daily cup of tea...! The tea tasting at the end is ok, if there is a particular tea you want to taste then make sure u ask, they seem happy to give it to u. I am not much of a cellar door sucker so all I can say about the gift shop is that loads of tea appeared to be sold whilst we were there. A real good experience and one I recommend.

This tea factory is located amidst a lush green surrounding, this adds to beauty of the place. The factory itself is nothing special but the staffs were very welcoming, the restaurant had a beautiful view of the tea garden and serve some tasty snacks. You can also take a walk in the tea garden and feel refreshed with all the green surrounding you. If you want to buy some tea , they have a nice little counter for tea where you can buy some nicely packed and reasonable priced tea.
Nice informative tour from plucking to processing! Tea tasting included! Beautiful tasting room and gift shop!

Brief tour all designed around tea sales at the end. Doesn't include a tour of the tea plantations or pickers which was very disappointing. A very rushed and disorganised tea tasting. Tea super expensive. Bizarre. Still, the brief factory tour was interesting. Look for a better tour which includes a walk through the plantation during picking time.

An interesting tour of the factory to learn about the production of the different types of tea produced there. The entrance is up a fairly steep flight of steps which may challenge some. You are guided round the various stages in production and see the various machines working (little in the way of safety barriers). Because of the machinery the guide is sometimes difficult to hear. At the end you get a cup of tea and exit through the shop (of course). The area where you are served tea has some outside balconies where you can take some panoramic pictures of the tea plantation.

Personalized Tea Factory Tour was interesting and free.  Tried tea samples and purchased some excellent tea.  Also, had flavored teas.  Our guide stopped here on way to Sigirlya Rock Temple.  Nice to stop and visit by minivan since the other half of our Tea Plantation Tour was taking the Train and our guide picking us up halfway due to time limitations.

Our driver/guide made sure that we didn't miss to visit this Tea Factory. It was busy with tourists, our guide walked us through the whole process with only some of the machines working in about 20 minutes. This young lady guide was charming but her English accent was very difficult for us to understand. At the end of the factory tour, we were directed to the Gift Shop Area and offered a complimentary cup of tea. Great tea along with a very good selection of teas to buy! The Management would do well to computerize the Billing System and also pay attention to the washrooms which require not only to be upgraded but also better maintained.

We stopped off on our way to our hotel in the area. We were shown round by a very friendly lady who told us information about the factory. This lasted about 20 minutes, we were offered a complimentary cup of tea at the end but we didn't stay. There was no pressure the but anything. We enjoyed our quick stop here and would recommend it.

Our driver brought us to this tea factory as I told him I was obsessed with tea. The visit to the tea factory was interesting. The lady walked us through to the entire process and we were lucky enough to see the huge machines in actions. She explained the process briefly and showed us the different types of tea they made. The overall tour took about 10 - 15 minutes. Photography is allowed here, unlike other places which I have read. You can then proceed to the store and purchase some tea - quite reasonable prices (SGD 10 for three large packets). We had lunch here as well. The fried chicken briyani was really good! And view during lunch is amazing as well.

Loved exploring the tea estate. The tea producing process was educational and  informative. Enjoyed the free cuppa as well. Brought some tea for home as well. However the equipments were not operational and found the staff explaining things in auto mode without answering any of our questions regarding the interesting process of producing tea.

Nothing to see equipment wise that was actually working other than one large tray of drying tea leaves. Staff were bored and not really interested in anything apart from chatting to each other. Only decent bit was tasting 4 of their teas. Good selection of teas on offer but they were expensive
Interesting tour on the tea making process in an old factory. Enjoyed the tea tasting after the tour and bought tea to take home from the shop.

It was an informative tour, learned a lot about tea making and visit to scenic tea gardens next to it. Bought some tea for home as well, however, this place is lacking good services. They were unable to manage properly the large tourists in peak season. Information about tea making is also not very detailed. No information after the tour for which tea to buy and the lady sitting on till is doing manual ledger entry instead of using calculator and computer. I must recommend avoiding this and visiting another tea factory.

We visited the tea factory on New Years Day so unfortunately none of the machines were working, which perhaps gave us less of an experience than others. The guide was pleasant enough and gave a good overview of the tea making process. However when we asked questions, these were not fully answered and we felt that she did not really understand what we had asked which was a shame. At the end of the tour you get to taste five different teas and then are encouraged to buy some to take away. It was a decent experience worth a visit if you are passing but nothing to go out of your way for.
Nice and got to see the difference of the tea types and production. Never knew tea leaves were hand picked, crushed, sieved, dried and seived again.

The are quite a few tea tours in the area. After visiting two in the area and one elsewhere I have a reasonable picture of the process, would be helpful if you could get it all in one place. Pluses: -all the machines were running, they were drying leaves, and you could see the whole process -you were allowed to take pictures -gift shop had good selection if you wanted something Minuses: -tour felt rushed, we didn’t stand still for too long so you could not actually take everything in e.g. there were some posters on the wall with general info, would have been nice if I could have actually stood and read it -the questions our group asked were not really answered, not sure if a language issue or not listening to the actual question being asked -felt like I was being stalked in the gift shop by person who lead tour, she really wanted me to buy something was the impression. Not sure if hey commission on purchases or what was going on, but it made me not want to buy anything. Reasonable experience but it might leave you wanting to try a second place in an attempt to get a bit more information.

I visited Glenloch with my partner during our stay in Sri Lanka. Our guide was kind and showed us the main part of the factory - nothing in depth but good enough. We did taste the different teas they have to offer and they were really tasty. It was good to learn a bit more but nothing was exceptional - at the end of he day the main goal is to sell you overpriced items!

Don’t waste your time coming here, you’ll leave disappointed.  Our female guide had no interest whatsoever in talking & showing us the factory.  Whole tour took less than 10 minutes. We also made the mistake of eating lunch here.  The five of us all concurred, that it was the worst meal & service in our 8 days in Sri Lanka.  We had the stir fried beef, devilled chicken, biriyani rice, fish & chips (photo below) & spaghetti. We told our driver of our terrible experience & he said “they just get so busy they have to rush”. Well.... that’s not good enough if they want us to spend our hard earned cash with them! Do yourself a favour & avoid this place! In general Sri Lanka has a long way to come in order to reach the level & expertise of service both Thailand & Bali provide to westerners.

What a amazing place.  We just drink tea and say what a taste.  But there are lots and lots of affords behind it.  Very nice process , high quality tea packed in front of you.  Make sure that you bye one.  And you can enjoy the hills of tea plantation. It's very cold. Please take warm clothes.  You can bye organic vegetables too.

Our driver suggested stopping here for a quick tour. Our guide took us through the plant and explained the process of tea making. She spoke very good English and answered obligingly. We also picked up some tea in the gift shop and it was very reasonably priced considering it was a tourist location.

Our driver took us to this factory. A lot of other buses here. The guide we received was very uninspired and just did the tour as quick as possible. The factory was quite dark and the machines were not running when we were there. We tasted some tea after the tour. Nothing special but we bought some packages of vanilla tea.

Stoped there on our way to Nuwara Eliya. Visit was rushed. The lady dropped us for a Tamil group which had just arrived half way through. Tea tasting was weak tea which didn’t make us want to buy much...

Lovely place that has opened it doors for the public to see how tea leaves are collected and processed. They are generous to share the process and you can taste tea before you decide which you will buy. The lady serving the tea was very friendly and was encouraging me to try the different teas and made the effort to serve me. The tea has a very fresh aroma and refreshing. Tried the white tea for the first time; it gives good complexion, I am told. Would have preferred the commentary from someone who is passionate about the work than someone who just wants to get the job done with.

We were taken through the tea making process of making black tea and told about white and green tea. The explanations were quite mechanical rather than related with enthusiasm. We were given English breakfast tea to taste. I would have preferred to walk around the actual tea plantations before getting to the factory. Worth a look if you didn’t see one before.

There was a tea factory tour where the lady took us into the production area and explained to us step by step on how tea is manufactured from tea leaves. She was answering our questions along the way w/o being disinterested. You also get a complimentary cup of tea at the end of the tour and may choose to purchase tea from the cafe itself to bring back home with you.
Look before you eat anything from the restaurant . I found this in my rice on  11 th December 2017 & check your glass before drinking anything .
They explained about tea and how they making it inside the factory what is the Proses very well.and how they catogarising the tea.overoll very go experience

Complete waste of time to visit this place. They provide a guided tour with a very very disinterested guide and then plonk some cups of teas in front after the “tour” (which in itself is a non-event) is out of the day. There is the ubiquitous shop which sells teas at a price far higher than what we usually pay in supermarkets in our home country. It’s free but that does not mean you waste precious time here. In a nutshell it’s a favorite of tour guides and drivers which is usually a good sign of a “tourist trap” or place to avoid.

we visited the glenloch tea factory and got to know about the tea bushes how they are grown and picked and shown the full process of what happens to the leaves after they are picked at the end of the tour you can sample different teas and are able to purchase we where amazed that you can get several different teas from bush ,was fun being show how they pick  the leaves and given a go at picked an enjoyable visit

have visited few times, Glenloch tea factory established 150 years ago, the factory tour was really interesting. Factory staff Nirosha & Lanka doing a great job, always provide many information and helpful. during the tour you can watch the Tea process from start to finish, not only that you can enjoy tasting few cups of tea, different varieties. there is a Tea shop but no pressure to purchase. you can find this place from or to Nuwaraeliya - Kandy. recommend the place always, will come again !!

We visited the tea factory at the moment where 2 busses arrived. Our guide was in a hurry because of these busses. We got a lot of information about the proces from leave to tea... with a lot of noise it was dificult to folluw the explanation, such a pitty. We had a tea taste at the end and a big shop where you can buy a lot of different tea .

Visited on a public holiday, so factory was quiet and only women there. We got a really informative (and patient!) tour of the factory and museum - comprehensive walk-through of the tea making process, with lots of hands-on show-and-tell (running the machines etc), and tea tasting afterwards where they also offer to brew what you're interested in (try before you buy). Yes, there are opportunities to shop and tip here, but absolutely not the hard-sell you experience elsewhere - even in the tea shop. Afterwards, we got a tour of the fruit garden. That part of the tour was a great hit (I learned a number of new fruit even if I thought I had a decent knowledge of tropical fruit). Recommend the place!

I have been here twice now on two different visits to Sri Lanka. The first time I came, I realized that I had not bought enough tea, so I tried to buy more elsewhere in Sri Lanka. Bad mistake. I ended up being offered the same tea for ten times the price at several places in Mirissa. So the second time, I made sre to stock up. Our driver came in to check on us as we were checking out. He did a doubletake at the size of the stack of tea boxes we were buying. But the price cannot be beat, even elsewhere in country. They have both bags and loose leaf available. I really enjoy the factory tour. As others have noted, the tour is the factory side only. I also wish they would take us out in the plantation. But the factory tour is really interesting. It is amazing to see how much they produce in a relatively small place and learn about just how the tea is sold. (Hint: it is sold in international auctions held in Colombo). The tea here is really good. My friend bought some black tea and gave it to her son who promptly made a cup. He came in saying "Oh my god, you have to try this tea!" She responded "Yes, yes. I have had black tea." And he answered, "Oh no you haven't! Not like this!" I understand the tea did not last long and now my friend regrets not buying more. I too am completely spoiled by the quality. I tend to only drink Glenloch Sri Lanka tea. I never felt pressured to buy anything here. In fact, the first time I came, I sat in their tasting room for hours just enjoying the gorgeous views and the excellent tea. On cup of white, one of black, one of green, and one of the golden flush (they won't tell you how they make that one). It was the first moment I truly relaxed and felt like I was on vacation. Next time I am in Sri Lanka, I will definitely stop by for more tea!

Our driver made a stop here on our journey from Kandy to Ella.  I'm pretty sure he got a kick back for doing it.  The plantation itself is pretty, but then they all are, as it the experience.  I thoroughly recommend going on a tour but don't but the tea at the end.  We were stung and just spent £20 on the most expensive English Breakfast Tea I'll ever buy.  Way steeper than Fortnum and Mason!  Taste the tea, but you can buy fresh leaf in a variety of shops in towns along the way for a fraction of the price!

The tea factory is like any other you will visit, however, the taste of the their brew was superb. After a round of the factory, they will give you taste of their popular (not their best) brew, which most will abviously like.  I had to ask for tasting their different teas, which my host readily agreed to.  I must confess I am a tea lover and have a weak point for Silver Tips which I found was up to mark and readily purchased two packs - one for myself and one for a friend who too is a tea connoisseur.  Worth a visit I will say.

Glenloch Tea Plantation in Nuwara Eliya is beautiful. The tea factory is spotless clean and the guides give good tours with simple explanations. Visitors get to drink their prized teas and there is variety of caked you can buy. A good stop as this area is filled with tea plantation and tea factories.

We stopped on our way from Kandy to Nuwara Eliya as part of our tour plan. This is such a great place. Scenic views all around - everywhere you look you just see lush greenery and all round beauty! The tea making process  tour itself was brief but the cafe stop was fabulous. We pickedup quite a few bakes (cookies, brownies etc) and also tasted some of their green and white teas. Also bought some Cinnnamon (which we later found to be almost 40% more expensive in Colombo) and their best teas to take home for family. My younger was nauseous and had thrown up earlier so we wanted him to eat something. He refused to have anything except chocolate cake. One of the staff in the restaurant actually went in to the kitchen and got him a cake (although it was not on the shelf for sale) and refused to even let us pay for it! All in all, a great stop!!
Visit is worth the stop in house guide has her talk down to a tea gift shop is well stocked.Take time to walk the tea garden the views around are amazing

My husband and I were originally going to go to another plantation which we found online but our driver recommend Glenloch Tea factory and we are pleased he did take us here ! We were given a free tour into the factory by a lovely woman who spoke perfect English . She was friendly and knowledgeable about tea . The factory was very interesting as you saw first hand the process of the tea . Very interesting . Afterwards my husband had lunch there with the free tea they served us . Good tea , mediocre lunch but you do not expect great food at a plantation . Good tea ! We bought some tea as. souvenir. We did not need to go see other tea plantations after we had seen this one . Worth a visit if you are in the area !

Beautiful landscaping, friendly staff, all tourists are made into small groups for a tour of the factory. A particular staff that speaks your preferred language is dedicated for the tour which was amazing. After the tour you can buy glenloch products to take home. We bought a gift pack of 4 different flavoured teabags and they are all very flavorful.

The tour was interesting in what it was, though we had a very disinterested, dry tour guide not only that a couple of cheeky factory workers tricked us into paying for a photo of the station they where working in (we hadn't seen the no tipping factory workers sign at that stage).
A nice stop to find out how English breakfast tea comes to pass. As ever very nice people and  short tour followed by tea (and cake). A beautiful area....
It was so useful and a worth visit to the factory...we loved the taste of tea which we preffered...thanks to eveyone who treated us very humbly..
Short visit, quick tour from informative guide, interesting. Quick tasting and visit to the shop. Toilets clean. Enough said.
The worst tea in srilanka Taste is nothing of srilanka Visiting the factory is interesting but the tea itself for sure the worst tea ever

I didn't know this place. The driver took me there and I've loved the place. The explanation  is very clear and illuminance. Leads you step by step into the creation of tea; white,green,black,strong and delicate. At the end they serve you a taste of all the  qualities and of course the tour ends in their shop where you can buy every kind of tea. After that it is mendetory to step into the tea plants to take some picture with their basket on the shoulders.

We attended on recommendation of our driver. It was worth a visit. Tour was free, quick but informative. Disappointed that the tour didn't include anything in the fields and focused only on the factory side but that was very informative. Free samples at the end was great and a first for us to taste several varieties side by side and learn the differences. I was so disappointed that there was no field tour component that I struck out in my own and walked amongst the tea bushes. Nobody stopped me and I enjoyed the foray, albeit with my wife scorning me all the way. Suggest you do likewise if you want the full experience. We bought some tea to take home which was pricey, but we felt assured of the decision later as our driver also bought a kilo for his own use (or so he said - see my review of Red Dot tours)

We enjoyed the tour of the factory and we ate lunch at the onsite restaurant (average and expensive for Sri Lanka). We had a nice lady taking us around but felt the tour was very short, we were then led to a room to sample the tea's on offer (had really bad heartburn after) and were then let into the shop to try and sell us some tea. We didn't buy anything but got some nice photos with the staff.

Visited this tea plantation,factory interesting how they produce the tea .Restaurant meal they seemed to be in a hurry asking me before I'd finished if I wanted anything else .Toasted ham & cheese sandwich disappointing.

Glenloch Tea was established 150 years ago and that in its self is quite remarkable to still be processing tea for export around the world. The tour was interesting to watch the process from start to finish and enjoy several tasting cups of tea at the end. The staff were friendly and we felt no pressure to make a purchase....but we did however and my family now wish me to track down were I can purchase it in Australia!

Tour and tea tasting are free.  tour is ok but not view of plantation, and not testing except one cup of tea so  tea tasting is a disappointment. If you want to buy tea, this is the place to be ripped off. A total no go.. it's a surprise how they are still on business. If your tour is taking you there, avoid shopping! after visit they send you directly to the shop... there is better place to go.

Tour and tea tasting are free. However, the tea tasting is a disappointment. If you want to buy tea, this is the place to be ripped off. A total no go.. it's a surprise how they are still on business. If your tour is taking you there, avoid shopping!

We took some friends to the Glenloch Tea Factory as they had never been to a tea factory. A lady spent 30 minutes showing us around the factory after which we were offered a selection of four different teas to taste. I would describe the overall experience as being 'average', with a bonus perhaps being that we were not charged for the tour. Instead, we gave a tip to the lady who showed us around.

The day we went there it was public holiday so had to see machines all at rest. In a way I think was good coz no noise of them. The guide who explained everything was a bit bore. She narrated everything like machine. Looked like she was tired coz they were running on skeleton staff.

We were given a quick tour of the factory. It was interesting to find out how tea is processed. We saw all the machines,etc. Tried only 2 different types of tea, they were ok. They have a shop where you're u can purchase tea. It would have been nice to go and see the workers picking the tea in the fields.

Glenloch is 2 or 3 hours drive from Kandy but it is well worth the journey if, like me, you have never seen a tea plantation before.
