En route you pass through interesting countryside including tea growing areas as you get closer, and there are great views as you get higher.  The factory tour and the tasting are really interesting and I am very glad I went.  One point: tea pickers are very poor indeed so they are very persistent if given a chance to beg: you should take quite a few small banknotes with which to thank them if you photograph them.

We had a brief visit to this tea factory, as our driver/guide took us there on the way from our visit to Pinnawala Elephant Orphanage to our next destination in Colombo. Really pleased we went. Had a full tour of the factory, during which we were told about the types of tea leaf, shown how it's dried and sorted into different grades before being ground down and packed. Followed then by a few cups of different types of tea, including the premium silver tips tea. A worthwhile visit and great insight into tea making. And no charge, other than a discretionary tip for the guide.

Original corrugated plate tea factory along the road to Nuwara Elia. Easy access with parking. Tour of the old building is automatic, with a young lady taking you on a fairly quick tour. She did her best, and answered questions with some interest. Other than that the tour is mainly designed to get you into the small shop. Sad to say, no effort has been made to make the shop appealing and to give it some charm. You need to buy something or no commission for the guide... To taste you get 4 types of tea, all quite decent, but not my favorite types. Small restaurant on site, with good quick bites at decent price. Bathrooms are at our own risk, although the mens has a nice view...

The information during the walkthrough was nice and was good to learn about the process of tea. Very interesting to see the amount of old and new technology used in this tea factory. Afterwards you get to try a cuppa & then choose if you want to buy products, at no time there was any pressure to purchase their products.

Our only experience throughout are entire 2 weeks in Sri Lanka where the people were not particularly friendly. The guide to the tea factory seemed frankly bored and going through the motions. When it came to the tasting, we got two cups to try, no explanation, it was virtually thrown at us and we were left pretty much alone. We purchased tea but there must be better factories to visit

During our recent 3 week holiday in Sri Lanka we called off at this tea factory for a tour. It was surprising how antiquated much of the machinery is. However, we learnt so much about the process of producing tea and how tea is graded etc. The tea tasting session in the canteen area was very good, with generous samples of most of the various tea grades on offer. Before leaving, we bought some boxes of loose tea to take back to the UK, although we weren’t pressurised into doing so. There are many tea plantations/tea factories in this area of Sri Lanka around Nuwara Eliya and our driver just happened to select this one.

visited as part of a trip to Kandy. Our factory guide was very informative and explained everything clearly. I was delighted to see machinery made in the UK and Ireland 100yrs ago still working. The tasting was also an experience, tasted tea I've never tried before. I've read comments about the tea not tasting the same at home. The main reason for this is the water not the quality of the tea.

nice tea factory on the way to nuwara elyia. when you stop, you get a short free guided tour through the factory and afterwards, they offer their teas for tasting. they don't urge you to buy something. but the the tea is worth it, so you will buy some. the prices are adequate, a long as you don't want to buy some white or golden tea (really expensive...) you can also do a short walk around in the fields.

As with most other tourists, our tour guide recommended this factory because he said most other factories do not have a guide who is there to explain the process.  There was a bit of rain and the factory was about to close (I think it was after closing time). Our guide, Priya / Preeti, was nice enough to stay back and give us a tour of the factory.  Since it was after closing time, the machinery were not operational, but she gave us a full guided tour and was also able to answer most of our queries.  She was a very friendly individual and made sure that she went through the full tour, even for a group of 3 which comprised of 2 adults and 1 child. We were then lead to the tea shop, where we were given a cup of tea to sample.  Then, she showed us to all the various products that they had for sale. They had a decent selection of tea in various shapes and sizes.  The tea is of good quality, having tasted various flavors and selections from what we had bought.  However, for everyday use, the product may be a little too expensive.  As a gift or a novelty item, this would be ideal.

Its a very informative tour, I have learned new things about Tea. I just a had hard time understanding the accent of the Guide and It will be a bit boring if your really not into the TEA because its a bit lengthy because you will literally go around the whole factory.. But basically the tour was nice, the hostess that guided us and assisted us was very nice. There will also be a free tasting of different teas so that you would have an idea if ever you would purchase some. You can also visit/walk through their plantation and they have very nice view of the mountains. (the whole tour was free of charge)

It feels like you are in the 18th century, the old antique machines everywhere. Work did not take place because of the holiday. It is very disappointing because I expected to see a modern factory as McWoods, which is nearby. We bought the most expensive tea for gifts what we found there, "The Golden Flush Specially manufactured For Royals, 15g costs 500 RP. What can I say ... terrible tea no taste, no smell. Now the tea is placed in cupboard because I did not dare lie to someone this donate.

Seems to be strongly recommended by tour guides, which is usually a sign that they have some sort of commission arrangement.  We're extremely frustrated. Our driver from aitkins Spence took us because he said our hotel (the heritance tea factory!!) didn't have a similar experience/factory.   When we checked into this beautiful hotel, we found out it has its own organic (which is a huge differentiator) tea plantation and factory which is available for tours, tastings, an experience plucking tea, and a gorgeous tea bar with tea available to purchase. The real kicker-   The organic tea from their estate is about 50% less then the Glenloch store.  Turns out this is likely because they have to pay the tour guide commission. Lesson learned (unfortunately too many lessons) about travel companies and guides' relationship with some stores and tour centers.   Save yourself the money and go get some amazing organic tea at a much better price.

On our first visit the guide was really not that interested and rushed us round , a tour bus had just come in and I think she saw  more chances for tips , we visited again a few days later and had  a tour from a much better guide and it was very interesting. I wonder how much production this factory actually does as on both occasions there was not that much activity in the factory, Tourism may be taking over as a hotel is being  built on the site . As big tea drinkers we bought quite a lot of tea , as a previous reviewer we have found this very disappointing on return home . The english breakfast tea has little taste and to get any colour you have to leave the tea bag in ...have not tried  any of the other teas purchased yet .............. Perhaps try to seek out a smaller plantation.

I had no idea how the different kinds of tea were processed before my visit here; and it was very interesting to see a real factory at work close up with an informative guide. Free cups of the finished product were available to taste and although it was, as usual, exit via the gift shop, it was nice that no-one put any pressure on us to buy anything
Always a pleasure to visit a tea factory, and learn their manufacturing process. Make sure you visit when you are around this place.

Like many others we stopped at Glenloch on our way from Kandy to Nuwara Eliya.   Because of the number of visitors we weren't able to find a guide who had been recommended.  And so the young woman who was available began to explain the tea making process.  Within moments it became clear that she would rather be elsewhere.  We began to feel that we were imposing as she recited her memorized script.  She  seemed  to discourage questions.   The explanation that she provide was adequate albeit quite basic.  After our brief tour we were ushered into the tasting room where we were offered a cup of tea.  She stood over us (more like hovered)as we sipped our tea and then followed us into the shop never more than a few steps behind.  It felt quite uncomfortable.....to the point where we simply wanted to leave even though we were planning on buying some tea.   Sorry Glenloch...we had hoped for a better experience.

We stopped here on the way to Nuwara. We found the factory tour really interesting and although it was busy our guide really took the time with us. There is a shop where we bought tea but didn't in any way feel obligated like some attractions (this was welcome) keep up the good work.

We were there last December. We stopped over for lunch which was not good at all. We had biryani which was plain yellow rice and a separately fried chicken ... The veg menu was catastrophic as well as it was tasteless. The waiters are very slow but with good intentions. The visit to the tea factory was done in a noisy environment and we could not hear properly the lady who guided us. The tea tasting was the only solace though.
I was able to see and learn about how Tea leaves are picked, sorted, how stems and other waste is removed, and what part of the tea is used in the brew.

Dont go by the crowd here. If the staff feels you are not going to tip them.. they will leave you all by yourself and will not even look at you. They hardly give one type of tea to taste... and in the store, the staff is only looking at western travellers. Instead.. visit smaller tea factories where you will get good personalised treatment which will make you buy some stuff. overall.. a bad experience.

The tea tea factory is one of only two where visitors are allowed. The tour guides are friendly and knowledgable. The process of how the tea is produced is extremely interesting, and finishes with a great cup of tea!  Plus you can  purchase freshly made tea.

Here you can see the process of tea - from drying process to packaging. Somewhere along the factory you can also see an old french grinding machine which is almost 140 years old (for exhibit purpose). And the best part of this visit is you can have a taste of their tea for free.

Good free tour of working tea factory with original 100 year old + machines. With a nice hot cuppa at the end. Anyone slightly interested in Engineering or manufacturing will enjoy this. I actually enjoyed this more than the temple of the tooth.
Nice walk on the tea blending process and visit to the tea factory. Its an educational tour but they expect you to buy tea at the end which is quite expensive. Some teas were really good.
Beautiful tea factory and friendly guides that walk you through tea making process. Complimentary cup of tea. Can go and walk up in tea fields if desire.

You do feel a little bit like you are on a conveyer belt here yourself as there are tours starting every few minutes. They only last around 15 minutes and then you are taken to try the tea. The tea sold in the shop is not the cheapest, but then you wouldn't expect it to be. The views from the top of here across the valley are lovely.

We found the tour of the very interesting and the experience  of picking the tea. I would agree with other travellers that it seemed very rushed to the point of just getting you in and out. We were offered a visit to the shop after having cups of the different types of tea,this we declined as I suspected it would be over priced I am sure that there are better ones in the area. So if you have a choice try somewhere else that might take more time with you

The tea prices are outrageous and the only explanation is they give a cut to the drivers to stop you off there instead of other factories that are much better and don't rip you off so much on the prices- 1000rupees for 100 tea bags of Earl Grey is ridiculous- don't get taken for a ride, unfortunately we did.

We arrived at Glenloch around 8.15 am, hungry and tired after almost 2 hrs ride from Kandy - so we wanted some breakfast, and some tea. Since the service started only at 8.30 am, the staff asked us to order our food and take a look at the accompanying shop. We ended up buying all kinds of tea brands from them. :) Breakfast was very heavy. We had ordered club sandwich, cheese and tomato sandwich, cheese and tomato omelette, milk tea and green tea. Green tea was on the house. And the milk tea was out of this world - so much so that we had to ask the brand, and each one of us bought at least one packet on Glenloch BOPF. You must try (and buy) this. The sandwich was too much for us, so we doggy-bagged them. But it was tasty. The service staff were very cordial. The place itself is lovely, a bit up the hill, with a sit-out that overlooks the hill. There was enough place to seat at least around 150 people at one time. After breakfast, we went for a visit inside the tea factory, and the young lady guided us and gave a brief history of tea making in a sing song voice. That itself is an unique experience. This is a short tour, and you must take it to understand the different nuances of tea production. Worth the time spent.

We had lunch at its restaurant. The restaurant is under renovation, and so it is very dusty. Food is expensive, cold and not authentic. If possible, I will not recommend anyone to dine there. In contrast, the factory tour is much more pleasant. Our tour guide is really friendly and patiently explained all of our questions. You may request more than one cup of tea if you are preparing to buy some. The factory was built 150 years ago, worth visiting.

The young lady staff who was our guide seems uninterested and tend to rush through her briefing. Her tone was certainly a put off and seems stern and smug. The only time  she perked up was in pushing us to buy the tea products. Overall, reception was unfriendly and not welcoming. I wouldn't come again nor recommend this factory.

We arrived at a quiet time. They provided a personal guide who was extremely friendly (most Sri Lankans are) and very knowledgeable. She explained everything very well, answered questions and let us wander, take photos and look around. We were certainly not rushed. They offered a cup of the locally made tea and a variety of tastings. All were extremely nice and we ended up by some for ourselves and gifts for family and friends. Some of the big name factories can be a little crowded, bug we found this one had a good balance. Not crowded, bug a god crowd in a looking.

Each group gets it's own free guide, however due to the large number of visitors, they rush the tour so that they can move onto the next group. Although the factory tour was a mere 5 minutes, it was quite interesting to see the tea making process (4 teas from a single plant). Thereafter they let you taste a cup of tea (no milk). But at this point, the guide disappears, so it's best to ask questions before they go. Then, the salesmen take over and try to sell you the overpriced tea. In conclusion, we drove up from Kandy to visit the tea plantations, and had we known it would have just been a 5 minute experience, we wouldn't have wasted a night at Nuwara Eliya.
Interesting visit to understand how tea is made, from the leaves to the final product. You can taste several tea and then buy what you prefer.

We were here early morning, so driving to get to the top and seeing all those lovely tea plantations couldn't stop my excitement as this is my first tea plantation visit. As soon as I arrived, my lady guide met me outside and was ready to give me the tour. She was nice and informative throughout the tour. I learned about white tea, green tea and black tea. Who knew! She was not rushing with her explanation and took time to respond to my questions. So much information to remember but who cares, all I know I had a nice sample of their delightful tea. I was given several choices and I was able to determine which suited my taste. The teas at the shop were quite expensive. I did purchased my favorite teas for myself and my friends and family. I am a tea lover and so I am glad to have this awesome experience at Glenloch TF.

we had a small tour in this tea factory and they explained the process of tea. and later they will provide complimentary tea. we did buy tea at the end but it is pretty expensive. we purchased multi flavored tea.

This holiday was our first visit to Sri Lanka and we really wanted to do a tea factory/tea picking visit. This one was recommended and organised by the local travel agent (ground agent for Kuoni). I imagine this is not dissimilar to other tea factory offerings and as far as I was concerned ticked all the relevant boxes. What surprised me most was that we were touring  a working, commercial operation and allowed to get up close and handle the (largely ancient) equipment and the tea in its different process stages. I was expecting something slightly more sanitised behind Perspex screens with UK-style endless warnings about health and safety etc but blessedly there was none of that. Our friendly guide gave us a brisk tour of the different stages but never hurried us when we wanted to look closer, take photos and generally dilly-dally taking the place in. Information she gave was hugely informative and I learnt a lot about the process. After the machinery we had a tea tasting of 4 of the teas (slightly disappointingly we were just left alone to sample while our guide disappeared - some tasting pointers or things to look out for would have added to the experience) then guided through the retail operation to part with money. We didn't mind and there is no obligation to buy anything and the prices were probably not unreasonable. Finally we had a brief tea-picking experience. Basket-strung-from-the-head photo opportunity rather than a picking experience but was good to do if only to appreciate how hard the real tea pickers work for their low wages. Doing this, my wife managed to pick up a leech too which wasn't part of the formal picking experience but served to again emphasise just one of the hazards of the job for real! (Could have been worse - could have been a venomous snake bite!). A must do if you love tea and this was a good tour in a real working factory with an enthusiastic guide.

Definitely worth a visit and really interesting to see the process. We tasted the equivalent to English breakfast. It was nice although our tour guide seemed to be impatient waiting right next to us until we had drank our tea so felt rushed. Didn't buy in the shop as v.expensive but tipped our guide.

Visited Glenloch as part of a 1 day organised tour. Tour of Tea factory and the process was very interesting. The tour guide was very friendly and informative and answered any questions. There was a tea tasting session at the end of the tour followed by the opportunity to purchase any of the tasted teas to "take home". Very interesting, especially for any tea drinkers out there.

We were welcomed by a lovely member of staff who took us around the Tea Factory and explained the processes to us. The machinery was the original and we had the chance to see the tea being made live. The views are breathtaking as it is but this was really quaint and a nice touch. After our tour, we were offered a cup of green, black or white tea to take in the view. They also offer their tea on sale to take home. They must mark this up considerably! The packaging isn't great.
Very interesting Tour on the tea factory. Friendly staff and ended the Tour with tea and cake. Best tea ever...

This tea factory/plantation was fantastic. I have attached a picture of our guide. Believed to be in her late 20's, she was very sweet, professional and knowledgable! Seeing the whole process of how tea is made was really interesting and I was surprised to learn that all different types of tea come from the same plant just a different leaf! I always assumed it was a different tea plant all together. We got to taste the tea afterwards and after tasting how fresh and how creamy the taste was, of course we had to buy some! I will be absolutely gutted when I run out of the tea! It tastes amazing. Our tea back home is nothing in comparison to here. I definitely believe this is the place to visit if you want to see a tea plantation/factory. I was told by my driver that this is the only tea factory still owned by Sri Lanka. This was sad to learn. Please visit this place rather than the places owned by large corporations! You'll never taste tea better than you do here. Also, if the owner of this factory is reading this review, the lady I have uploaded a photo of deserves a promotion, she was superb.

A worth visit for everyone who drinks tea. Guide was friendly and details shared were informative. We got a nice cup of tea at the end of the tour in a breathtaking location overseeing the sea of tea. BOPF, BOP, Pekoe, OP, Green, Sliver...  - learn more about this when you visit this place. :)

Cute girl guided by easy English. I can understand clearly. It was good experience. I recommend to visit here :) ガイドさんの紹介で訪問しました。 可愛い女の子が英語で説明をしてくれました。わかりやすい説明で、英語ペラペラじゃなくても十分理解できました！ 紅茶が出来るまでの工程を工場内を見ながら説明してくれて、最後に試飲も✨ショップでお土産も買って満足です！

The guide was very friendly and fluent. The location is breathtaking. I would have preferred to walk around the tea plantation for a longer period. Reasonable prices though I expected to find cheaper offers.

we had a very fun and informative visit. the guide was very clear and friendly as well as knowledgeable about the tea processes. we also got the chance to pick tea!!! and we drank a lovely cup of tea at the end.

Brought to this tea plantation factory by my tour company, and provided a perfectly spoken English-speaking guide. Interesting information about the tea making process, white tea, black tea and royal flush Ceylon tea levels of tea produce, which we have no idea about when we pick up tea packs in the supermarket. Very informative, complete with tea tasting and an opportunity to buy some as well. Recommended.

Our guide took us to the Glenloch Tea Factor as part of a Ceylon Tour we were on. What an amazing place, I didn't realise the amount of processes involved. The Tea tasting was very good at the end and we purchased quite a few to take home to the UK. My favourite was the Black Tea with Vanilla. Unfortunately I'm on my last box...

I came here on my way to Kandy. It was a really helpful insight into tea and how much effort goes into making it! The staff were all really helpful and informative. We tried cake and tea at the end which was a really nice touch! Definitely recommend 🌱

Tour if the tea factory was good and very informative, especially considering I know nothing of the history of tea. I was impressed with what I learned and interested with what they showed me. I had a chance to try several teas afterwards and yes, there was an opportunity to buy, although there was no pressure. This place is worth the visit. Purchased two boxes of tea for 20,000 rupees $20

Everyday we consume many cups but never gave a thought of how we manage to get into teabags. Well the wait is over. A brief introduction of how things are managed and kept and packaged are shown and told. Once you know the details, you will learn to enjoy that cup of tea more than ever. The tour educational. Sri Lanka is known for Teas. So find one which you enjoy most :-)

A tourist trap.  One is quickly shown around the rather smallish factory.  Complimentary tea and then ushered to a rather pricy factory store.  Where products are sold at double the price.  I will suggest one goes there sees the factory and not buy anything.  Also I think the driver or tour operator gets a cut here.  Also the packaging does not have manufacturing date or product details.

Nice tour conducted by a lady who explained it thoroughly and well on how teas are planted, processed, the various grade and the best way to drink it:).  The tour finished off with sample of teas from the plantations and as usual like many other tourist places, head to the shop - they are reasonably priced and its something that you probably cant get back home!    Nice day out in a nice cool weather.   I really enjoyed it.

The tour conducted here was very comprehensive and was absolutely free. The guides answer questions clearly and there is even an opportunity to taste the tea for free! Tea sold here is decently priced.

This a nice relaxing tour around the tea factory. It's interesting to see how it gets made, it's a laborious task and the machines are still quite rudimentary. Enjoy some tea and cake in the restaurant afterwards, there are nice views. The tour is free with a tip box system in use at the end of the tour

Very enjoyable seeing a working tea factory with all the smells and noises in the factory. Our guide was extremely good and knowledgeable and the workers in the factory were full of smiles! Free cuppa at the end didn't do any harm either.

it's smaller than Mackwood Factory but still nice place to visit. the tour was nice and guide is a nice guy after that we have been given some cups of tea and it was awesome so I went to the store and bought some packs and that's really recommended. things I didn't like are the tea lounge were you get your complementary tea was awful and need to get finished and have a nice interior and the exterior .. same goes to the store . still they have the best tea ever (royal tea).

The tour takes <15 mins where they will explain about the process of making the tea. Afterwhich, they will let you sample some tea. There's a shop onsite. Its up to individuals whether they wish to buy.

We spent a pleasant hour here having the factory tour & then a cup of tea & fish croquettes in the cafe. I wouldn't go out of my way to visit this place, but it was free (apart from the croquet & tips) & did break up a long & winding trip from Kandy to Ella

Did this on our way back from Kandy to Bentota. Not a great tea drinker myself, but my wife wanted to visit a tea plantation. After stopping on the road to see a tea picker picking the shoots, she quickly moved the car to give these to my wife, but in turn expected some Rupees. The tour was quick, reasonably informative, but the guide spoke too fast and was difficult to catch all that she was saying. After the tour we got to sample some tea, and inevitably was led into the shop where my wife purchased, yes, you guessed it, some tea!! Was OK, but could have been a whole lot better.

As with most of these things, our Virgin Holidays tour guide stopped us here, and I'm sure they all get a lovely cut. The tour was interesting enough, though not that informative as the guide's English wasn't amazing. The "complimentary" tea was a good redbush. The shop was badly laid out but the pricing was clear and there was no hard sell. The tea was cheaper than it would be in the UK, but again I'm sure it's double what it would cost elsewhere. But at £10 for three boxes it isn't a scam, just a bit of a tourist trap. Although as we were there a bus load of local schoolkids arrived for a tour, so it can't be all that bad. It was a welcome cup of tea and a walk on the long drive from Negombo to Kandy, but not worth going out of your way for. And it's overpriced, but £3.50 in the grand scheme of things isn't worth fretting over

Got an informative tour of the factory and the teas they produce by a friendly young woman, saw some of the tea-picking action, and were served 3 types of teas to try. The tea shop seemed a little expensive but was worth it considering the effort they put into the tour.

The Glen Loch Tea Estate is one of the oldest estates in the area and boasts to be more than 100 years old. The staff is nice and courteous.  They have very intricate knowledge of the picking and processing of tea. Tea tasting session was interesting and we tasted 4 kinds of tea. Shopping area is a bit premium but you can buy some exclusive stuff if you are a chai fan. Ps : very clean restrooms

We really enjoyed our tour of the Glenloch Tea Factory. Our guide was very knowledgable. One tip though - if any of the factory workers offer to pose in a photo they will expect to be paid (we had only just arrived and had no idea what was a reasonable tip amount - the 20 rupees we gave was not well received).

we visited today. I knew that after the tour and explanation they will give tea to drink and then the sales pitch. The green tea to taste was good. I decided to buy their Golden flush which is their own premium brand. I paid 4000 LKR for 50 tea bags. Having read another review that most tea bags had only dust, I tried to try it out in my room as I am staying in Nuwara Eliya today. The tea is not dust but leaves in a pyramid bag (the stronger variety). The tea did taste good with no strong after taste. Good to drink without milk or with just a little bit. I am sure the price will not be this high (£20) if it is not for foreigners. But this is a trend I have seen in this first visit to SL.
Never buy anything from the tea factory they will cheat you. We purchased worth Rs. 13000/- (Sri Lankan) tea from outlet of factory all most all the containers are having tea dust...

We stopped by en route to Nuwara Eliya. Our guide was very informative, showed us the place with a lot of interest and even explained how the different types of teas are categorized,. Since then we've been speaking the language of "op and bop". Good experience if you haven't been to a tea factory. The factory is just a conventional one with nothing much different from the others.

It's located on the road to Nuwara Eliya. Stop by, for a guided tour of the entire tea making process, a hot cup of tea and before leaving, an option of buying some expensive local tea. The views from the plantation are a photographer's delight.

We were taken on a whirlwind tour of this tea factory by a completely disinterested guide who then dumped us in the canteen for a free tea. There is no choice of teas to try. The tea factory itself was nothing special with very little going on, and we learnt very little.

The difference at this tea factory is that you can actually get very close to the process, touch the tea and be near the machinery.....(almost such that you worry about the health and safety aspect.) With a very friendly guide taking me around you can touch the tea that is in the withering process and then get near the machines that cut and sort. This factory really does allow you to get close and that is the best part and it is a smaller and "friendlier" place. The tea tasting is pushed a bit more as they do sell the different teas that are made there.

Visited the factory during a trip to around Sri Lanka. Gives you a real understanding of the tea you drink on a daily basis, with lots of samples being an added bonus. A special mention to a young Sri Lankan working at the sight named Indicab who it was a pleasure to have met and made the experience all the more memorable. The views were breathtaking as well! Make sure you visit if your in the Country!!

We stopped off here on a 4 day tour in Sri Lanka. We drink loads of tea; probably gallons of the stuff every day but we didn't really know how it went from plantation to cup. Our guide took us to this plantation on our way to Nuwara Eliya and the first thing we noticed were the breathtaking views; absolutely stunning vistas down the valley. We were taken into the 'tea factory' by a lovely young lady who proceeded to explain to us the end to end process from the leaves being tried, cut, sorted etc. The smell in there was amazing and we have since discovered that it is the same smell inside the pack of tea that we bought there. At the end of the educational tour, we were treated to a cup of the tea, which provided much needed refreshment after the heat of the factory. We bought several boxes of high quality tea for 1000LKR each, which is around £5 and seems expensive but it is absolutely genuine top grade tea and the taste is amazing. Plus, the tea bags are so strong that we use ours twice! If you're up this way then it's definitely worth a visit and a nice rest break from the road!

We had a short, but informative tour which we found extremely interesting. This plantation is set in a stunning setting. We had fun tasting various teas and of course, being British, we bought a good range home for our home and for gifts. Lovely tea I hasten to add.

Our family were on a tour and we stopped off here. It was extremely fascinating and the kids enjoyed it thoroughly. Even the kids tried the tea. (Only one enjoyed!!!). We had cake with our tea and even that was cheap! I highly recommend this location!

Free to enter, this working tea factory offers you an informative tour during which you can take photos and video and follow up with a free cup of tea.  We bought some tea back to the UK with us and it is delicious!
You can check tea plantation, processing at one glance with surrounding awesome natural beauty. verity of teas are available to buy.

Very informative and interesting short tour of the production plant, surprising to see how simple the process is. Finishing with a lovely cup of their tea (of course) and surprisingly for Sri Lanka, free! Was amazing to see bus loads of Chinese tourists packing huge boxes of tea to take home!
Very well guided tour of the factory. Amazing assortment of tea at their factory store. Would definitely recommend this to people who would like to buy authentic Srilankan tea.

Spent about an hour here and enjoyed a tour given by a nice Sri Lankan young woman where we learned about tea making pretty much start to finish. It does seem miraculous anyone can make money producing tea given the amount of manual labor involved! We got an inside tour of the actual production line. Afterwards they provided samples of their BOPF tea and of their white tea--if you know anything about tea (which we do now), you know that white tea is relatively rare and expensive. So of course we then bought some at the well-equipped retail shop.

Visited this tea plantation on route from Kandy. Our guide was knowledgable and you can walk through the factory and get a good feel of the process. We visited MacWoods after here, and found Glenloch offered us a 'small' plantation feeling, whereas in MacWoods, it was a bit more of a tour round their museum.

We had a well rehearsed but very interesting explanation of the tea leaf production process, followed by complimentary tea tasting. Photos of the machinery were allowed. Then we were ushered into the shop and closely followed/guided around with some pressure to purchase. However, we both enjoyed the whole experience and felt that we learned something new about tea.

We had such a lovely tour and learned a lot about the process of tea making. Our guide was super and we were really with how many languages he could give the tour in. You're allowed to take photos and feel/smell the tea leaves at different points in the process. The tour is free and includes and complimentary cup at the end. We got to sit out on the balcony and look out over the scenery.

Stopped off here on route from Kandy to Nuwara by our driver. Looking forward to it as it is in such a beautiful location. The actual tea factory not the nicest looking place on the outside as it is just a "corrugated iron" sheet structure but it is very old. Had a quick tour of the manufacturing process from tea leaf to export sacks. Quite difficult to hear and understand the guide on occasion. Then a nice tasting complimentary tea in their adjoining cafe. and then bought some tea from the gift shop. This was MASSIVELY overpriced and when relatives opened the box on our return to the UK, there were hardly any tea leaves in the pack. Ripped off as usual!

We went on 2 tea tours, this one and Pedro - go and do the Pedro tour and refuse the invitation to go here unless you really want to take photos inside (as they're banned on the Pedro tour). Our guide processed us through the tour and told us the rolling machine was a cutter then offered us a cup of tea but seemed agitated when we actually wanted to drink it - she eventually (after about 5 minutes) exclaimed that she was going to leave to take another tour which was a relief but instead remained awkwardly until my wife gave in and we left our tea and went to the shop to buy something and be released from our shadow. As per many of these places, you're pressurised into buying at overinflated prices and if you're on a tour and trusting your guide you often end up falsely believing that the prices are actually normal or that you may not have a better chance to buy tea! The tea prices are determined by where you're from so if you can convince them you live in an ex-pat community in Galle then you may be onto a better deal? I dread to think how much less I could have paid buying premium Ceylon tea in the UK. Pedro was a nicer experience and there was no pressure - actually they didn't even bother to tell us there was a shop where we could buy souvenirs etc. It was 200 rupees for the tour but worth every one of the 100ish pennies that represents.

This is a chance to see how the tea as picked starts the process into your cup. The actual tea factory looks like every other one in the area, apparently using a design perfected in the 19th century, with machinery invariably from the UK.  It is however interesting to see the process in action, starting with a sort of fermentation where a lot of the water content is removed naturally, through a grinding into small segments and then a final drying.  The there's a lot more to it, particularly the blending, testing, tasting and packaging, but those are the initial steps. All the time specialised machinery is doing the real work. After an informative tour showing the process you are invited to a tasting session where you can try and distinguish between the various products.  Finally, there is the opportunity to buy some genuine Ceylon tea.  I have to say that I did not find the selling to be very pushy. For a visit of just over an hour I found this to be very interesting.

Stopped here on way to Ella, did a very quick tour of tea production followed by a 2 cup tea tasting. They could have been more informative but they were rushing through visitors and there was a large shop for you to buy in. If you want a quick intro into tea production and you do not have the ability to go elsewhere it will suffice but the Uva Halpewatte Tea Factory near Ella offered a far better experience

After being to Tea Factories in Sri Lanka in the past, I had told the driver not to bother as my experience is that you gain very little knowledge and are ushered as quick as possible to the shop to try a Luke warm cup of tea and then harassed until you give up and buy a packet of tea. However the guide assured me this one was different and I have to say it was. There was a very friendly guide who showed us around and gave a very informative lecture with props on the process. Afterwards we were offered tea and were in no way harassed to buy tea. Actually the reception in the tea shop was so pleasant I ended up buying tea! Price was very reasonable as well. Certainly worth a visit if you want to visit a tea factory. Rather noticeable were the empty car parks of factories I had visited before!

The lady who provided the tour was very knowledgeable and warm, she had excellent spoken English and the tour was interesting and not too long or short. The shop was quite expensive at the end but made for nice browsing. Great views of the plantation area and a trip worth making if you are in the area

I and friends visited this tea factory as part of our Sri Lankan tour in January 2016. After sipping some teas as part of the tour, I left my iphone, without noticing it,  on the table and went on to their tea shop. Only 5 minutes later did I realize I had left my phone behind, and rushed to the tea room to get it back. Surprise: all the empty cups and my iphone had been taken away. I reported to the staff members present at the tea room and the tea shop but nothing was done. At the time I left my iphone behind, the room had no other tourists but our group. Therefore I can assume it was taken my a member of their staff. Shame! I reported to the police and my iphone was day after day located at a location near the factory, at a gas station, according to the GPS from my friends' phones. Which means it was not a tourist who stole it. Grace to the Glenloch Tea Factory my Sri Lankan tour was turned into a nightmare.

Tea farms, impressed with the visit, you get to learn not everything, but a lot about tea, the farming, the processing etc till the packaged product and the varieties of tea and their benefits. we got a first hand experience at tea plucking too, not that easy as it looks, its hard work. having aromatic tea at the end of the tour was really great & a visit to  their store seeing so many varieties and different packaging was impressive.

Our next visit was planned for this factory on way to Nuwara Eliya and we spent some quality time as all of us are qualified engineers and liked the opportunity to look at process and production of tea. The process is quite interesting but the factory lacks of safety to employees not wearing shoes and helmets. We were offered taste of tea which was satisfactory. We also bought tea of various varieties. The price is a little high.

Visited the tea factory on our way to Nuwara Eliya from Kandy. The driver stopped there to show us the Glenloch tea factory. Were shown the process of tea factory. Then we were offered tea. And of course last we told if we would like to buy some tea. Bought Green tea And BOPF. We paid Srilankan 1000 rupees for 200 grams for both the variety. To our surprise we were not given the purchase bill. On the boxes the price was not mentioned. Even upon insisting also the sales girls refused to give the bill. Later in Colombo saw Brands like Dilsan Tea available for less than half the price. During the tour the guide told us that Dilsan Tea bought tea from Glenloch.  Felt cheated by the Glenloch tea factory. Please do not buy. Even the tea does not take any thing great after paying some crazy prices. No wonder they are not issuing bills as they are cheating tourists.

It is touristy but not a tourist trap. It is well worth a visit - you get a tour of the factory and insight as to how the process is from picking the tea to selling it. And there is a shop where you can buy a variety of Glenloch tea - We bought a lot and have not been dissappointed, the tea is great, nice flavour.

Enjoyed seeing and hearing how the tea manufacturing worked, all explained by a lovely young lady. Saw the different types of tea, then into the cafe for a cuppa. Not very nice tea at all which was a shame as we would have purchased for gifts etc. I feel they need to put more thought into this aspect of the tour if they wish visitors to purchase tea. Quite slap dash at the end, perhaps if they introduced a tea tasting experience, similar to a winery it may be more enjoyable.

The tour starts with you plucking tea in the gardens,  which makes you appreciate your daily cuppa a little bit more. Then you are taken through the factory where your guide explains the process of tea-making.  At the end you can taste the tea. Quite interesting. The shop, however, is too expensive. Considering that we are in Sri Lanka and buying directly from the producer, 6 euros (1000 rupees) for 300g is really pushing it. And they push you...  So we bought a package which is really huge.  I would have appreciated several smaller packages of different teas that fit better into my suitcase.

Tour was rushed and had a very commercial feel. The service was really, really poor at the tea tasting afterwards.. This was a real pity for Glenloch, as my partner and I ended up spending well over $200 at another factory with better service. However, this is the best tea factory that I went to in terms of photographs. Everything was in working order, and it was fully staffed. I got AMAZING PHOTOS. Go to some other tea factory if you really want to learn about the tea. In fact, I recommend visiting several tea factories in Nuwara Eliya if you can.

Enjoyed a visit here being greeted by a guide on arrival. She explained the tea manufacturing process from start to finish, short tour of the working factory and different types of tea followed by a complimentary cup of tea in the lovely cafe. Exit via the shop. We bought a couple of presents to take back home.

We hadn’t planned to stop here but our driver gave us the option so we decided that we should given that we all drink tea !  The main factory is some distance away so this is more of a heritage factory than a full blown production unit.  What it does do is show you how tea goes from leaf to pot in what is a relatively straightforward process – the machinery is quite old and never seems to have heard of Health and Safety or machine guards! The tour was better than expected and the cup of tea at the end welcome although we didn’t buy any having done so before. The museum is interesting but not inspiring. I think it was worth the short visit purely for the insight but had I not gone I wouldn’t have been disappointed.
You get a free tour and a free cup of tea. Afterwards you can buy high quality tea from their shop. The tour is very insightful, the scenery is really nice and the prices are decent.
Best place to hear about the tea manufacture . The staff is so nice and you feel that they do their job with a big pleasure

I never went to there myself so this is only a second-hand review and is more about the tea than the place itself! A close French friend of mine visited there recently. She told me about her trip which was very interesting and the photos she took were amazing. Stunning views and an interesting tour of the tea making process from the tea leaf gathering in the fields to the factory. She brought me some of the tea back to try, knowing I love my tea. They do a wide variety of teas as you can see from the photos. I tried a full bodied black tea which came loose in a packet for preparing in a teapot. It similar to English Breakfast blend but with an unusual slightly earthy after-taste to it. Not nearly as good as the brands I drink in the UK. I was wondering if the tea was organic, completely natural or something, but my friend said not. One thing my friend told me which was interesting...she said a lot of the big tea brands that sell teabag tea, buy the ¨tea dust¨ (stuff they don´t sell themselves as it´s not good enough for loose tea) from the Glenloch Tea Factory. That surprised me. It just goes to show, brand names can be misleading and people are too trusting of them. You need to see where your tea comes from and how its prepared.

We stopped for more of a relief stop after visiting the elephant orphanage. The driver said they maintained good toilets, he was not joking. After, we went for a tour of the factory which was excellent. We understood the gradation well. It seems I have been drinking factory floor dust all these years! After the tour and tasting, we were lead to a shop where we stocked up on quite a few ornamental packages to take home to friends. This way the manufacturer gets a fairer share of my spending dollar!

We visited this factory as it was selected by our driver/guide. Mondays a bad, as no tea picking takes places on Sunday, so half of the tour was looking at machines, standing still, as no activity took place. The guide was friendly and knowledgeable, and the free tea tasting was very nice. there are nice views from the tea house.

We visited while on a bike tour. They factory has a nice balcony where you can sample tea (we had four kinds: English Breakfast, Green, White, and Special). They were all quite good, and were a healthy sample size. The balcony overlooked a valley, and was quite a pleasant view. However, there is some major construction happening right below the balcony which was a bit noisy, but hopefully it will be terminated soon. The tour guides wanted to know if we wanted to eat, but all they had was mostly things we don't eat (breads, pasta, cake and cookies, etc), and it was on the pricey side, so we declined. However, the other guests seemed to like their food, so it might be a good place to eat. We were then taken on a factory and plantation tour, both which were very interesting since to that point I really didn't know how tea was made, and the difference between black, green, white, and a new tea that I had never heard of 'silver tip'. Apparently it is mainly about the different age of the leafs, and then their is very little difference aside from the fact that black tea is fermented and then dried, whereas the others are steamed. We then bought some tea in the gift shop, which was very reasonably priced, and then I went to have one more delicious green tea before we started to ride again. To my great surprise, they gave me the extra tea again for free since I had bought some tea in the gift shop. The gift shop had all sorts of teas, in all types of formats. They had all the teas mentioned in the samples above, and they had mixes with herbal ingredients. They also had most in loose and bad format. Lastly, they had packages in different sizes and containers. I wanted pure green tea, and I was offered a 200 gram loose tea in a simple box for 1100 rupees, or 100 gram in a display tin for 1000 rupees. Our tour guide was very nice, and was informed. Overall, if you like tea, or are just looking for a nice view, consider stopping here, or at one of the many tea plantations along the way.

It was very interesting to see the old buildings and machinery and that not much has changed over the last 100 years when it comes to tea manufacturing. The guide was very friendly and helpful. The tea that they have for sale is a bit expensive but very good and i guess you are paying for the experience.

Typical scenario where driver stops, you receive a free tour a sample to drink in the shop where tea to purchase is placed around you while you drink. It's actually worth the visit, a guide talks and shows you the process involved in tea making from picking to packaging, which is interesting, the smell of tea is very strong. There is also a small museum. The free cups was in itself a welcome refreshment break.

Our guide recommended breaking up our journey from Nuwara Eliya to Kandy by stopping at this tea factory (we'd passed many on our way - this was one of the last). We declined to take the tour as we've been fortunate enough to go around a tea factory whilst in the Seychelles and we were were aware that the processing area would be hot! We went into the shop area (which had a good selection of teas) and admired the views from the balcony. We were still offered a free cup of tea, despite not doing the tour. As bird watchers we also noted a few Hill Swallows, a notable species having a very limited distribution in Sri Lanka and south west India.

Recommended by our driver and listed in our copy of Lonely Planet, we had a very good brief stop here. Lunch was simple but very tasty, the tour was short but very interesting. In fact, they were bagging up tea during the tour which meant we got to see the factory working. Afterwards we had a complimentary cup of tea - which was lovely. Shop is not over-priced for being direct from the source. A worthwhile tea factory tour.

Very informative and interesting tour of a Tea Factory, I will never look at a teabag in the same way. Check out the machinery that is used to process the tea leaves, it is from a bygone age but as the guide said it is still the best way. After the tour of the factory enjoy a cup of tea on the shop/restaurant terrace overlooking the plantation, then browse the shop for tea to take home.

My husband and I visited the tea factory as part of a 4 day tour we had booked through Hayes and Jarvis called "Cultural Kandy and Tea." The tour of the factory was detailed and the guide was very informative. He told us to pose near the tea for photos etc and took some photos for us. We viewed the whole tea making process, which was fascinating. However, at the end of the tour we were taken up to a terrace and provided with a cup of tea (which tasted fantastic by the way) and the guide stood over us, clearly waiting for a tip. My husband explained to him that our other guide (who was driving us around for the whole trip) had not yet taken us to a cash machine and so we had no money to give for a tip. We apologised profusely, however the man just stayed there stood over us, which made us feel very uncomfortable. After a while he gave up, a lady came over and took our cups away quite rudely. I was feeling quite mortified by this time and thought I would at least buy something from the gift shop with my bank card so that we would at least spend some money there. Again, the staff in the shop were abrupt, the lady who served me practically threw my bank card at me. We couldn't leave there quickly enough. I think it should be made much more clear that tips are expected here; we always tip generously, however I think sometimes it helps to remember that we had already paid several thousands of pounds for our holiday, which included the tour. It also wasn't our fault that our driver hadn't taken us to an ATM machine! (I had actually tried to take money out at the airport but he advised against it). I would recommend the trip, however please be advised that you will not be treated very nicely if you don't tip the guide.

We had a very good tour of the factory. Our driver dropped us off at the factory and our guide gave us a detailed description of the process, let us take photographs and he also took some excellent photographs of us. The guide also took us to the edge of the plantation for further photographs, then off to the cafe for a selection of the different complimentary teas. The guide was excellent and looked after us during the time, I think the tip helped, but he was very helpful and we enjoyed the trip.

The Glenloch teafactory gives you a very insight in how tea is processed. You visit all parts of the plant, can touch the tea (interesting from a food safety point of view..) and see how the machines and the workers work. The guide we had hardly was able to explain the process, so it is advisable you have some processing knowledge yourself

We spent a fascinating hour at the Glenloch Tea Factory. A really interesting factory tour explained the tea-making process, from picking to packing, followed by tea & cake in the tea shop, and a chance to buy tea in their shop. Friendly, well-run, a lovely place to visit.

Agree with most reviews that the tour was informative, good tea etc.  Unfortunately, after we just sat down after ordering our complimentary tea, our guide demanded a tip from us in a hostile tone.  We had every intention of tipping and buying tea but chill, we didn't even know the tour was officially over! Bad attitude and entitlement!!

Interesting and informative stop on any trip between Kandy and Nuwara Eliya. A guide takes you round the factory explaining the process and the function of each of the machines (absolutely necessary - there's a withering area, a rolling process, Fermentation/Oxidisation process, drying machine, grading room, etc.) and you end up in a tea-tasting cafè, on a balcony which gives you a panoramic view of the Mataweli River valley. Finally, there's a shop.

This is the first tea factory o e gets to see while heading to Nuwara Eliya. The factory has guides to take you on an informative walk around the tea factory. It is pretty informative for children as well as adults. Finally one gets to enjoy tea tasting and you can also buy the tea from there. It makes a good gift for people back home.

Our driver took us there for lunch with us having no idea that we will get to visit a tea factory as well. A good surprise. In short food was good. We were served with complimentary cups of tea as well which tasted really refreshing. Tour of tea factory was not too long but the guide gave good insights on how different kind of teas are prepared. Well recommended.

Very informative brief tour of the tea production that ends with a tasting.  Ask to taste several of the teas if you can.  The "Royal" tea is the best and worth a try.  Great spot for some gorgeous photo opportunities and good shopping opportunity.

Stopped here on the drive from Kandy to Ella. Good ( especially as its free;-) tour of a working factory with smiley staff and the chance for a nice cuppa at the end. God's vote from the terrace as you stop on some pretty great tea and of course you can make some purchases at the gift shop after ( expensive though and you can get same quality for less elsewhere)  ease your guilt by dropping some dosh in the tip box before hitting the road once more.

As a person who drinks about 5 cups of tea per day I have to admit pure addiction!  So it was fascinating seeing how Tea is produced, cupping and pressing fresh tea leaves and learning about the different types of tea. The visit itself is free of charge, but there is the obligatory teashop and Gift shop which seemed expensive by comparison to the supermarkets but on coming home produces an excellent brew. There are apparently another three or four tea plantations nearby but this was the one recommended by our very trustworthy driver.

We called in to this tea factory and were treated to a tour of the factory which was very informative Following the tour we had a free cup of tea which unlike se of the bought ones in the supermarket has no chemicals and is so nice u don't need milk or sugar Entrance is free also

If you are a tea lover then this will be a tour for you! This is a small working tea factory and you see the whole process of how the tea gets from the bush to your cup! We had a lovely guide to show us around. There was a free cup of tea at the end of the tour which we had on a verandah overlooking the beautiful tea plantations. There is also a small shop where you can purchase tea produced at the factory.

the people get paid £4 a day to pick the tea and they still smile and want you to smile back ! you a free cup of tea that is produced where you have just seen we brought some home and its amazing ! better than your tesco,asda sainsbury's

Glenloch seemed smaller than other tea factories we had seen around, but we really enjoyed it. We had a tour with another couple (who were French - our guide lady said 'I will explain slowly because they are French' lol!) to see how the tea was produced. The machines were fascinating and the whole area smelt so fragrant. After the short tour, you are given a cup of tea which was really nice (and I don't like tea... yeah, I said it!) apart from the massive spider I could be hanging from the rafters. Husband bought a couple of boxes of tea. All in all a nice little stop!

Visited this on a tour, while driving to Nuwara Eliya. This factory had a great overall experience. We started with a tour of the processing plant. How they sort tea, dry it, break it down, sort it. After going through the different types, we were brought to a cafe where we sampled some tea and had chocolate cake. Pretty tasty. And such a beautiful place. I recommend getting a seat by the balcony! I would also recommend a stop by a tea picking farm to see the hardworking, underpaid women that produce tea. Enjoy the tea and the experience

If your visiting Nuwara Eliya then this place has got to be a place you visit. It gives a great insight into the countries tea industry plus you can taste the tea for yourself. We all enjoyed out stop here they have a good car park and you can see the full tea production process not to mention the spectacular views of the surrounding tea country
interesting little tea factory which is a small branch of the main plant in the tea country. nicely done though and the guide showed us the tea making process which was interesting.

A tea factory and visitor centre situated in a stunning location with panoramic views of the surrounding areas and tea plantations An ideal stop off point for a snack or meal Glen Loch has a great restaurant with an outside terrace to view the scenery. It does host coach parties so can be very busy if several arrive at the same time It is possible to have a free tea tasting. Samples of the various teas (Gold, Silver, Green and Breakfast) are served in china cups. Although I am not a tea drinker I enjoyed the experience very much Of course there is a shop where you can buy the tea and many other gifts

The Glenloch factory is a picturesque and intimate factory. You are taken to a tea tasting upon arrival complimented by stunning views of the surrounding mountains and plantations. The factory tour takes about 15 minutes and our friendly Tamil guide gave us a lot of details on the tea production process, showing us and explaining what each machine was used for. I learned a lot on the entire process. You can buy Glenloch tea at the shop after the visit.

The Glenloch tea farm is a calming and relaxing place to walk in. You get to see many locals plucking tea's. The Factory is small but worth taking the tour of how tea is made, of you haven't visited any other tea factory before. They provide some valuable information about white tea, black tea, green tea etc and is open to questions. The tea being sold is worth buying especially 'silver tips' and 'the golden flush '.  I won't recommend the green tea as it's like any other green tea and neither is the BOP/BOPF too special although they make a big deal out of it. Try the tea before you chose to buy one :)

Take the tea tour (it is FOC) only if you haven't visited a tea factory before - a quick 15 minutes thru the factory to see fresh, green tea leaves turn into fragrant Ceylon tea and learn the different types of tea Glenloch produces. Then, of coz, the obligatory walk thru the tea shop where you'll be sure to pick up a box or two to take home. The day I visited, the place was filled to the brim with Chinese visitors who were buying tea by box-loads to be shipped home to China. It was a riotous affair - all that for tea ;0)

Glenloch tea factory is smaller than some others, and thus attracts somewhat less tourists. The excursion was quite short, skipping the growing of tea bushes and getting directly to processing tea leafs. The guide was very nice and friendly, and even though she offered not much information herself, she was ready to answer as many additional questions as we asked. After the excursion was a short tasting of tea (good), and a shop with quite a good selection. Upon trying purchased tea at home, I can say I'm not disappointed at all.

Glenloch was magical. We were doing a road trip with tents around Sri Lanka and stumbled across Glenloch whilst trying to find somewhere to pitch out tents as the sun was coming down. The lovely owner let scamp in his garden, whilst we had a private function going on in the guesthouse. Not only that but they provided power, tea, breakfast etc  - they could not have been more hospitable if they tried, and the best thing is that they didn't expect or ask for any money from us. Of course we offered it but they did not seem to expect it. It was the highlight of my trip, the view was stunning, food delicious, and experience unforgettable. Thank you Glenloch!

Our driver took us to the Glenloch tea factory on a day trip through Ramboda and into the mountains towards NuwaraEliya. We took a stroll up the hill to see the tea pickers and on the way down two children came to 'chat' to us. Their English was good, but scripted- asking where we were from and welcoming us to Sri Lanka with a handshake. They said they were 12 years old. As we reached halfway back down the hill they started hassling us for money. This was not unexpected, but it saddened me. They should be at school, but obviously rich tourists offer more prospects to them and their family. We didn't give them anything as doing so would only reinforce this practice. Our tour guide was very friendly and answered all of our questions. However, when we reached the 2nd machine where they 'swill' the leaves, one of the workers started to get really angry and was shouting and being pretty abusive to our guide. There is obviously a problem here that they try to cover up, but it was really unpleasant to watch. The tour was quick and the tea at the end seemed good (I tried green and black). There was no pressure for tips or to buy, although I felt obliged to do both. Let's hope the tea lives up to its high price tag once I get it home! Oh and by the way- avoid the toilet unless you are really desperate- awful and door didn't even close!

Glenloch Tea Farm was established in 1867 and this Scottish factory remains to be one of the best producers of various teas in Sri Lanka. I like they kept the old original facade of the main building. We were toured inside their factory to see the process on how different types of teas are made. They have shown various samples and even offered some teas. I was able to buy White and Silver Teas considered premium. And now know that Green Teas are still rhe healthiest.

The drive to the tea factory from Kandy is breath taking, I loved the beautiful roads, the tea gardens on the sides of swirling roads with water falls at various locations before we reached the Glenloch Tea factory which had its own Tea Garden, there are no tickets for this visit, you are introduced to a worker there who takes you around covering from the beginning like what kind of tea leaf is plucked and which parts of it is used for white tea, Green tea, black tea and how each of it is processed before they are packed off and sent to Colombo for auction to be exported mostly to European Countries. We get to taste different kinds of tea and also buy from their shop inside the complex, it is better you buy it here as it is not available in the grocery stores outside in the market and if you happen to sight it the price is very high.
It was refreshing that there was no hard sell on both tipping the guide nor having to buy the tea. We ate lunch there which was ok although mine took a while to arrive.

The tour lasted about an hour and fifteen minutes... This estimate includes the tea tasting. The factory is located among the tea plantations, which is not only fitting but very picturesque. The tour is extremely well organized and informative. As an David tea drinker, I learned I knew nothing about my favourite drink. Of course there is a gift shop where you can buy the tea produced at the factory... I left with 3 boxes.

My husband and I were enroute from Kandy to Nanuoya to catch the midday train to Ella. Our driver recommended we leave very early so we could stop in Nuwara Eliya to visit Glenloch as it is Sri Lankas tea capital apparently. Tour was just the two of us and the lady spoke excellent English and zipped us around the factory in about 10-15min which was fine for us and free (just tip as you please). Tried a couple of teas and bought some as well (no pressure to buy which was nice).

If you're travelling between Kandy and Nuwara Eliya, it's well worth popping in to this place.  You get a free tour of the factory and are shown how the various teas are made, which leaves are used and the best way to prepare them once you're at home.  You also get a tasting of the teas of your choice and a charming old lady will then offer you a piece of cake.  Inevitably, you have to pay for it and give a tip to your guide (despite the fact that there are large notices all over the place telling you not to do so), but we're talking pennies and it seems only right, so you do because it's worth it.  You've learned something more about the country and about the tea and about the people who actually live and work there on a daily basis.  What's not to like?!

The trip to this tea plantation through winding hills was a bit well nauseous, but once you get there the fresh mountain air is a pleasure to breathe. The size of the plantation overwhelms and the smell of tea fills your nostrils. The tour guides were well dressed in traditional sarees, and there were different tour guides speaking different languages that could be booked. Our guide took us through the factory explaining how different teas were produced. We could take photos with the staff and were not asked to pay for the photographs as is the practice at some other tea plantations. Tips went into a box at the end of the tour to be shared by the workers. We were given a cup of Broken Pekoe tea at the end and then taken through to the tea sales area. There wasn't much pressure to buy, but we did buy some Glenloch Masala Chai and Broken Orange Pekoe Tea. The tea here is the unblended variety and hence a little more expensive than what one would get in the market. On the whole it was a good experience.

We were a little time pressed and this suited us down to the ground. It got us into the tea country quickly enough from Kandy (a smidgen over an hour). We got a bit of the view of tea-country, and a fifteen minute tour of a tea factory. I'd like to have spent more time - they could perhaps beef up the tour but it was well worth it. I wish I'd been there when the factory was busier but neither of us regretted this visit.

This was an interesting little tour which shows the process of making tea. We found it quite informational, and you get to sample the tea at end. There's a little restaurant you can eat there with good views.

Tea has always been a bit mysterious in my part of the world. This tour showed all the stages of production and explained how different teas are handled. There was plenty of time to ramble around the plantation as well. Workers eager to pose to earn extra tips. Interesting that they asked for tips to be put in a box to share among all the workers instead of just to the guides. Seems like a good move. Nice cup of tea at the end and mercifully none of the usual sales pressure. Really enjoyed it. My only regret is that the machinery was so noisy that I missed a lot of the commentary.

We stopped in this tea factory where we discovered how the tea is made from the leaf. Good explanations, nice place and good tea. We enjoyed our visit and even if buying tea here is certainly most expensive than in super markets or other places, it is still a pleasure and a good memory.

Visit on recommendation of my guide. Tour of the factory, well explained, nothing in a hurry, though I went solo. Bought some Gold Tea, White Tea, Golden Pekoe and Silver Tips after the tasting. Decent lunch with stunning views over the mountain and the lake. Maybe there are better tea factories, but I was quite happy to have visited Glenloch.

The company sticks hand written stickers over the Tea Packages. These can be easily removed and a new sticker attached. So when ever you visit, you would probably see a Tea package that was manufactured very recently. It only occurred to me after returning home because the sticker came off easily by the time I returned home to Singapore !  ZERO star for hand written labels ! and certainly overpriced ! Scottish name with Sri Lankan standards of labeling. I used their bathroom, so its 3200 LKR for bathroom usage and cheap Tea from a company with unprofessional labeling. God only knows if it was packed several years ago or just recently !

We stopped here at our guide's recommendation (not sure if commission was involved - though we were assured by many Sri Lankan vendors that commission is a way of life).  It was interesting to learn about the tea making process, but the tea is very expensive, and the toilets were truly revolting - the dirtiest I saw in Sri Lanka ( though our guide usually protected us and wouldn't stop anywhere dodgy).  After driving up the road we saw some beautiful looking tea factories that looked much more enticing.

Reviewer Location: North York Moors National Park, United Kingdom
Review Text: Our driver brought us here so no idea of the costs! However a very pleasant and informative tour round a tea factory with a perfectly capable guide. We enjoyed it and there was a cup of tea at the end. OK so there was a factory shop but absolutely no pressure (fairly novel in our experience of Sri Lanka). Clean restrooms too.

We had a very interesting and informative tour of this tea factory and we really enjoyed it! I was a little skeptical before we got there, thinking that it might be dull or rigged for tourists but it was great learning about all of the different teas. The tour guide was very knowledgeable and was able to answer all of our questions, and we had the chance to try some of the teas after the tour too. Highly recommended if you're looking to visit a tea factory in Sri Lanka.
It's a must to visit a tea factory during travelling through Sri Lanka. We had a short guided tour in the factory which was interesting. Good for buying some gifts for people at home,

Reviewer Location: Vila Nova de Santo Andre, Portugal
Review Text: Beautiful landscape and very interesting tour inside the factory with a very friendly lady explaining all the tea processes! Once more we learn something and enjoyed a cup of delicious tea! As usual people in the tea shop were very kind and professional. We bought some tea and we were very pleased to be there.

Even though there were tour buses, the two of us got our own private tour.  The girl did a good job explaining things, and was able to answer our questions. It's in a beautiful area, and you can see beautiful views while you sit and enjoy the free cup of tea after the tour. There is a lot of tea to purchase, and your guide will help you but won't be pushy.
Very interesting... A lot of work goes into producing that perfect "cup" of tea! They have a well stocked shop where various blends of loose tea can be purchased!

We visited this tea factory in october this year. It is'nt very much. The total tour takes about 10 minutes and for me it was'nt interesting at all. The lady that guided us was not very friendly. We were only with 3 persons and I think she rather had a busload of tourists. In the factory is not very much to see.

One of the few experiences in Sri Lanka that felt incredibly genuine and honest. Our helpful guide walked us through the inner workings of the tea factory explaining very clearly each part of the process of how is tea is made - from leaves to your tea cup! Walking through the factory you see the ladies working on the machines big smiles on their faces eager to have you come touch and smell each part of the tea leaves experience. It all ends with a chance to have a lovely cup of tea or two with the hospitable people at the factory and perhaps walk away with a packet of tea or two if you'd like to - but no pressure is put on you to buy anything. I'd highly recommend this experience to anyone with an interest in tea or even just to see the inner workings of a quaint place like Nuwara Eliya!

It's interesting to see the stages tea goes through to become from a leaf to tea pack. There was a guide explaining and going through the old style machinery in the factory. good Information to know about tea so you can know the difference between good and bad tea and the variety. Tour ends up by tea tasting and you can buy from their shop. Personally i felt it's a bit over priced. We had a chance to take some pics in the field where the ladies were picking the tea leafs

Interesting old style tea processing factory and equipment.  Some old equipment is preserved for historical interest.  Our free tour guide was mechanical and perfunctory but as there were only two of us, I think she was keen to get to the next (hopefully larger) group of tourists.  Free cup of tea in the tea shop was OK but limited choice to select from.  The limited selection of tea packs on sale were ridiculously priced. If you want to buy tea in Sri Lanka I recommend you visit the markets where the locals buy.  We got some lovely silver tip tea in a small spice shop in Galle at very reasonable price.

If you're interested in the tea making process then you should stop here. Not the largest but very informative. Friendly and knowledgable tour guide, cup of tea at the end, beautiful views from factory and a shop to buy the various teas afterwards! Tea pickers stop picking at 3pm so if you want to see that, time it accordingly- although not a must because if you're driving in the area you will see this happening as the tea factories cover the mountain!! Hire a driver- the views are gorgeous! The sun drops quickly and it looked quite bleak around 5pm when we were leaving but at 10am the following morning, the sun was shining and it looked spectacular! I loved this!!

The drive from Kandy is quite spectacular - it's ideal to hire a driver for this trip. The tour guide was informative - at last we know what white tea is, what differentiates green tea from black tea and how tea gets it's different strength of flavor. It's a free visit and naturally you can't help then buying in the tea store afterwards. They should think shout branded tea pots - that would be a welcome and much bought item.

What a fantastic place this is.  So full of history and demonstration of the hard working people who patiently pick the tea leaves that we all enjoy around the world.  We did a short tour that is free but there is a box to place tips for the staff.  They share these which is a good and fair system.  Then you are able to do tea tasting and select tea for purchase. I got carried away shopping again but it is so fresh how can you revisit. I would buy more of the exotic white and silver tea next time.

Myself and 16 travel companions dropped in at this Tea Plantation and Factory on the way from Kandy to Yala. It proved a welcome and informative rest stop. A young woman showed us around the factory floors, providing us with valuable descriptions of the tea manufacturing process from cultivation and picking to how teas are selected and packaged. It was actually quite absorbing. We finally enjoyed cups of Broken Orange Peko Fannings tea, about the best, and made our purchases. The views from the tea house and shop are quite stunning! This was one if those felicitous stops we were glad to have made; I recommend this Tea Factory heartily.

Its a nice place to stop-by on your way. They serve you good tea and take you around the factory showing the whole tea making process. It has a nice lobby and I feel the tea options they had were also not overpriced.

The second of the 2 tea factory tours we went on. The other was at Pedro, and we feel this is the better one. A comparison of the 2 below Glenloch : It operates for most of the day, and we got full access to the factory floor. And as close as we would like to the machinery. In total the tour was 45 mins around the factory, and we could take as many photos as we wanted.
