Has a nice shop area at the end, where you can purchase, and also sample for free, their offerings Pedro : stops working at 10am, as they told us they do most processing at night. We came just after that, and it was being washed down. No point coming on a factory tour if it's not working. Also they really didn't want you taking photos, and asked you to put the camera away. Got just 1 sample of tea  and it is their budget offering. Winner : by far it is Glenloch

The factory is the same as others, but the tea lobby is very nice. Good to look and have a tea. I thing, their tea was the most expensive of all, where I been, but try the lobby, the shopping is not the must.

We stopped here between Kandy, en route to the Heritance tea factory hotel. Beautiful scenery surrounds this working factory. A polite young lady took us on a short tour of the factory teaching us the processes in which tea is made, White, Green & Black. We were allowed to take lots of pictures and at the end were offered a fresh cup of Ceylon tea....perfect. It was served in the little shop. There was no pressure to purchase anything, but we did. Overall a nice stop off.
Old factory building requiring severe renovations, the tea shop also not upto standard when compared with nearby factories like Blue Field and Labookele Tea Factories.

Visit to the Glenloch Tea Factory on the way to Nuwara Eliya was my second visit to a tea factory after the one i visited in Munnar. We were taken around and introduced to the process of tea making starting from plucking to the final product which makes its way to our home. The factory is very neat and it takes about 15 mins to see all the process involved in making some of the finest black tea in the world in terms of its distinct flavor, aroma, and strength. We were treated to a cup of black tea and what stood out was the wonderful aroma. There is a shop from where you can purchase a variety of tea. If you happen to visit Nuwara Eliya, do visit any of the tea factories. It hardly takes a hour and it is not every day you can see your favorite tea processed in front of your eye.

A must go place!  We were greeted with traditional Namesty, and lots of smiling faces. A lady named Kamaleshawari took us around and guided us thru the factory. It is quite a neat place. They also have a very nice tea lounge and shopping places. The tea made there is not of very high quality maybe. The blend wasn't of our liking! We stayed in a place just above the factory. The Glenloch villa, very nice place! I am really thankful to the tea factory Incharge for making it possible for my package to reach Colombo airport before we left Srilanka. Really nice people!!

On the way to Nuwareliya from Kandy, this factory is located near pussawella. Nice place situated amidst the tea estates. Lot of tamil women working in this tea factory. A person named mrs.sasikala explained us about various types of tea and tea leaves processing. They also offered us a cup of aromatic sri lankan tea free of cost. It tastes excellent. Nice place to relax and sip a good tea.

The Tea factory is located in a natural scenic backdrop.A cup of hot and tasty Ceylon tea is served to us.I had a factory tour.Very good explanation about the production of tea was given by one the Glenloch staff. Excellent place to tour.

On the way nuwara eliya great stop ever for lunch with excellent nasi goren and other set menu , very hard to find descent food in this area And also the free tour of factory is informative and free cup of tea is also gr8 There is a shop and No pressure to buy

Super quick tour (7 minutes) and far from interesting. The whole point is getting you to the shop. I wanted to see an actual tea plant, but in vain. We took a second tour the day after at Heritance tea factory which was superb!

I think there are probably more "up market" tourist-y tea factories in the area but we enjoyed being shown around the whole process and seeing some of the very old machinery as well as the more modern processes,  We had some tea afterwards and although no-one pushed it we did buy quite a lot to take home with some decent knowledge of what type is what.  I would definitely go to the toilet somewhere else though, grim....

I visited glen loch on my recent tour of srilanka . We had a free tour of the factory, by a very polite young man and then taken for a taste of the tea. There was no pressure to buy any tea, though  when you see the shop you can't help but buy some! All in all a good stop off on our journey.

OK, having read the previous reviews, lets try and give some balance.... The tea factory is a wonderful relic to the belief, that if it isn't broken, don't mend it and in common with other factories, the process has not changed throughout the centuries. Similarly, some of the machinery is well over a hundred years old and in fact the tea factory is in effect a working museum. Yes the tea in the shop is overpriced, we we found this to be true at other similar establishments and as for the taste...don't forget that the tea drunk in England is blended tea, a concoction very often of teas from a number of countries. Pure tea is often drunk without milk and can be an acquired taste. You cannot visit Sri Lanka without visiting a tea factory and Glenloch set in the uplands in Nuwara Eliya is a typical set up. People wanting tips is typical of the culture and tourists should not be surprised; wages are very low, so If you feel a service has been carried out, then a small reward could be given, but if not, keep your hands in your pockets. The same applies to overpriced tea !

En route to The Heritance Tea Factory we stopped off here. It was awful!! And the toilets even worse, with a man wanting a tip, absolutely ludicrious!!! We were showed round the tea processing factory by a young women who was quite obviously exhausted and sick to death of saying the same thing!! The shop was good with plenty too offer but no change and  I was forced to ask around the room if someone could help. It wasn't until our driver intervened and protested on my behalf that all of a sudden change was found......the whole place was in a terrible state. The carpark was being altered, but not finished, the same with the extension. Something is definitely going wrong here??!! Such a shame!!!

I didn't visit this place. A friend did and bought a box of tea for us back home as gift. It had a suspicious smell and tasted awful, sour, kind of reminded me of the smell of peel of lychee. It appeared to us that it wasn't just some cheap tea; instead, something was really wrong with it. One of us started to feel weird in the stomach after drinking it. So you can probably visit this place again, but we don't recommend buying tea from them.
After the lunch the steward says only visa cards  what is this such a  massive place shame on the management

I would have given this 4 stars if it wasn't for the relatively hard sell at the end of our tour with tea prices which are ridiculously high.  £4.00 for a small box of loose Earl Grey Tea when it costs less than £1.00 at Cargills is simply too steep. As to the museum, our whole family enjoyed learning about tea and seeing the old British machinery from the 19th century.  It was easy to imagine the workings of the factory and it was an informative trip down memory lane.  I think the factory tour is free but the museum cost £2.50 to get in.  As Tea is part of the Sri Lankan culture now, a visit to some kind of museum should really be on your agenda.  Not sure if this is the best one but it certainly gives you a good insight into the differences of green/black teas and what manufacturing processes are used.

Interesting quick tour and cup of tea. Looks like nothing has changed in 150 years! I'm not a tea consumer but to me it tasted like everyday supermarket tea.  The was no big pressure to buy.  Left a tip in the box provided. They could have made a nice presentation of sampling but didn't bother.  Lame.

Naturally the Tea factory is one of the highlights of a visit to Sri Lanka and the Glenloch has many original features and makes a great photo call as you pass through the various production stages.  The guide was good and was seriously looking for a gratuity from the moment the tour started. We were offered a luke warm cuppa at the end of the tour in the visitor centre so beware. This is a great retail opportunity and the visitor centre is poorly laid out with a limited selection of teas to buy as gifts to take home  when compared with others we saw on the up Newara Eliya and compared with tea gardens we had visited in Southern India and Malaysia.  If fact I bought most of my tea later in my trip from a Tea merchant in Galle.  The difficulty with this venue is that it was selected by the tour company so we just turned up in the car park.  If you read this and have a choice make sure you check out some of the other tea gardens, yes they all have Scottish names.

This was an unexpectedly interesting stop off on our journey from Kandy to Nuwara Eliya. We were given a free tour of the factory by a sweet young lady and it was very informative and interesting to see how the tea is processed and to see how antiquated it all was. We felt no pressure to tip or particularly to buy anything in the shop - although we did pick up some slightly overpriced but fresh tea in the shop following a cuppa.

I visited The Glenloch Tea factory with my family. The tour was very interesting and the guide excellent. We bought 8 packs of three kinds of tea to take back to The UK with us…what an idea gift we thought! We also bought some tea for ourselves. However, when we tried to drink the tea after returning home it was unpalatable. The Ginger tea for instance tasted of dish-water, quite disgusting. The friends who we gave the tea as gifts were, without exception, in agreement. I apologised to them. Maybe we bought a bad batch? So I emailed The Glenloch Tea Company and reported what, when and how it tasted. They didn’t answer let alone acknowledge. I checked the email address on their site several times and it was correct. I waited. Two weeks later I wrote again. No response. Two weeks again and I wrote now three weeks on and not even the courtesy of acknowledgement, a reply or even better an apology! I now believe that they must have so many complaints that they just don’t bother to answer. Therefore I would most certainly choose one of the other plantations to visit but if your guide insists that you visit The Glenloch Tea Factory enjoy the tour but be strongly advised NOT to purchase any tea in their shop.

We had a great time at Glenloch. It was very interesting to see how the tea is processed and even better to enjoy a nice cup afterwards. The view is breathtaking and the Tea is excellent. You will find a great cup here.

It's always interesting to see how stuff is made (and not just on Discovery Channel)... They show you the   Very basic and traditional way tea is made!  And then you can try it all... And buy whatever you want.  Best gifts you can take out of Sri Lanka.

Our driver took us here as an unexpected "treat". Very interesting to see what it take to make something that we wll take for granted. The process is very dusty and noisy, but not a sign of masks or ear defenders - a union would have a field day here! Well worth a visit with camera to capture the various stages and look forward to a free cup of tea at the end of the tour.

Being Indian (now living in america) we know the importance of Tea. A cup of tea in the morning gives a kick start to the life. We had detailed view of the Factory and could see how tea is processed from leaf to packed bags. It was interesting and the factory staff was eager to explain whatever we asked for. The restaurant of the Factory was updated with all variety of tea manufactured here. I bought two packs for the house in USA.We visited this factory during our visit to Sri Lanka in Dec.2012.We were on our way to Nuwara Eliya when we took a break here.

It is very quite place where you can get information about tea fabrication and its history. Also you can have a lucnh or dinner in the reataurant. Prices is not high and quality of foods is very good. I you are not the maniac of tea don't buy tea in this place. Because it is expencive, but not the best. Just enjoy history, nature and meal :)

We visited the tea factory in June 2013 as part of honeymoon. As it was raining we were mat by very friendly staff from our car with umbrellas!! The tour was extremely informative and interesting. The staff were very friendly, they took photos of us let us touch the tea etc. There was no admission fee so we tipped our guide and bought some tea!! We were given tea to taste too. A great place to visit!!

We didn't know anything about tea so found this was very informative and fascinating. Felt like our tour girl was in a huge hurry to finish the tour though. Disappointing that the tour was only the factory not the fields too. Haven't tried it yet but bought the strongest tea at 1200 LKR for 400 grams.

We really enjoyed the tour of Glenloch handles by a lady named Mrs.Uma. She showed us all the basics explaining how tea is processed from leaves to final dust. Nice process views. Also enjoyed a Hot cup of Black tea at the end. Worth visiting and buying a pack of Export quality fresh tea. and there are many varieties of tea ranging from green tea to golden tea.

It was great to see tea leafs be produced into tea. The guide we had was informative and eager to answer any questions about the tea they produced.  We say down for a glass of tea after the visit, and yeah bought a little bit too, but hey why not the tasted good and the tour was fun.
A cup of tea will never be the same, now that I have understood and seen the complex process involved!

Beautiful nice girl guided us through the whole process of making tea. Very interesting experience to see and smell. Not any easy from the harvest to the final product. And although I am not a particular tea lover I have to say that the taste of the provided sample was simply great and definitely from time to time I have tea instead of coffee.

This is a typical stop arrange by the taxi drivers and tour operators to put tourist in commercially tourist shops. They sell it as a "tea factory tour" but is basically a show around the factory to end in the factory souvenir shop to be force either to tip the tour guide or to buy a very expensive selection of tea's. This is very common in this part of the world. You would see this kind of stops in Thailand, Indonesia and even in India. The Spice Garden is something very similar and its around the corner. You might buy something that you like but at a very expensive price (for Sri Lanka). But don't allow to be push around with this methodology. If you don't wanna stop or buy, nobody can force you.

As I have only ever visited one( this) tea factory I really can't say how good it is in comparison to others. What I can say is that we really enjoyed it. Didn't take too long, say the process from start to finish, saw the the classic scene of the tea pickers at work, old but functioning machines drying sorting and rolling the leaves. Very informative guide and a great cuppa to finish it off overlooking the amazing hills. Really recommend this place for a visit

On our trip towards Nuwara Eliya we stopped off for a visit at the Glenloch Tea Factory. The Guide shows you upstairs in the tea sorting room and explains the process involved in tea production. The machinery is very old but obviously still does the job. Workers seemed used to having tourists watch them work. You can take photos. Even thou there is a clear sign not to tip the Guide you are put in a position to discreetly pass him something. I did not see the Tip Box. After the tour a very nice hot cuppa is provided. No idea what type we were given as we were left in peace to enjoy it. No pressure made to purchase any tea as the shop was busy with a bus of tourists. We did not have the opportunity to walk amongst the tea bushes but our driver very kindly offered a stop further down the road.

My taxi driver took me from Kandy to Nuwara Eliya to visit the Glenloch tea plantations which has a 150 years old Tea factory.  I enjoyed some beautiful scenery on the way with waterfalls and lush green tea estates on the hills. The tour of the factory was very interesting.  It is amazing to see how the green leaves are taken through various stages to turn it into the black tea we all enjoy.  The tour is free, but visitors are expected to put some money in the Tip box in the cafe, where everyone is offered a complimentary cup of tea. I as well as a few other visitors had picked up a leaflet on this tea factory from a tourist office and it had an offer of a free mug on it.  But unfortunately all of us were disappointed as the cafe did not honour it.

We found the Heritage Tea Plantations beautiful as we were driving through the tea country from Kandy to Nuwara Eliya. Our driver stopped at Glenloch Tea Factory to show us how tea is being dried and packed to be ready for a drink. We visited the tea factory late afternoon, so we could not see the whole process. In spite of this, our guide was very nice and he explained everything while he was taking us round. It was so interesting! We got a sample cup of tea to taste their product and then we could buy tea in the shop. We enjoyed our visit here and brought a few boxes of their nice tea home!

We were very excited to visit the Tea plantations and drove three hours out of our way to do so. Our driver took us to Glenloch Tea Factory. The grounds were lovely and it was fascinating to see the process that goes into tea. I certainly will never drink tea without thinking of it again. However, our guide was very rude. We felt very rushed the whole time, he never fully answered our questions, and even though we tipped him more than we thought we should have, he asked for more. I was also very interested to try the different types of tea that they have (similar to wine tasting), yet they only gave us one complimentary cup of tea and did not even tell us which variety it was. The best part about our visit here was the restaurant down the road which had just opened up. It is called the "Oak & Ray Tea Bush, Ramboda". It has a stunning view, great buffet, and will be beautiful when it is finished being built.

Our driver took us here on the way to the Heritance Tea Factory hotel.  It was a really interesting visit.  We never realised just how many processes went into making tea.  We really do take it for granted with our tea bags back home!!!  A gentleman took us round who was the amanger, showing us the full process, we could take pictures and the staff were smiling whilst working away non stop.  After the factory tour he took us to see the tea plantation next to the factory so we could see and touch the tea bushes.  Once the tour was finished, he took us to the shop where we had a complimentary cup of tea which was delicious.  My husband gave him what we thought was a reasonable tip, considering there is a tip box in the shop, we shouldn't be expected to give twice.  He was the manager, was certainly on a better wage than the tea factory workers.  He mumbled something under his breath about the tip not being big enough.  We just politely smiled and walked away!!! We bought a box of various fruit teas for us to enjoy at home.  Worth a visit but make sure you don't have the greedy manager show you round!!!!

We really enjoyed our tour of this tea factory and learning how tea is made. We had no idea it is such a long process. You are given some tea to sample in the cafe at the end and then inevitably we bought a fair amount to bring home. The only irritant was the lady in the shop who followed us round as we were browsing the teas almost hassling us to buy!

My family and I went on a succinct interesting and varied tour which we all enjoyed and learnt something from. The guide was very pleasant, informative and genuine. The tour is free however there is a staff tip box at the end. Finished with a magnificent complimentary cuppa not surprisingly but splash out and buy cake. Surrounded by stunning scenery

Interesting free tour of an old tea factory with some of the original equipment still there, all the workers were toiling at their various jobs from sorting, sifting, drying the tea to packaging it for auction.  Our guide was a bit perfunctory and difficult to understand but most of the processes were obvious.  One thing to note, all the workers were barefoot. At the end of the tour you are offered a cup of tea, either black, green or white (white is the most flavoursome) and then can purchase from a variety of boxed tea, a bit overpriced as most tourist items are in Sri Lanka. When we were there there were several coaches and people in the cafeteria, so be aware it is a real tourist stop, but interesting if you want to learn how tea is processed.

Stopped here on the way to Nuwara Eliya - in the middle of fantastic countryside - and was a fascinating insight into how tea is made. Something we take for granted. The factory and machinery is quite old and it felt like a real working place which we were fortunate enough to see - the whole process was very well explained too. The tour was free and the guide was very nice and informative and there was none of the 'hard sell' that you get at some of these places. Complimentary tea at the end and some nice tea products in the shop. We really enjoyed our visit and it was one of the highlights of our holiday.

It tools us 2:30 hours drive from our hotel in kandy to this place. The view on the way was spectacular, where u get to see the tea estates, it's all green around you, and if you were lucky as we were, it will rain on the way there. Once we reached the place, we were greeted by a lovely lady who works there named Ganga. She took us upstairs and started t explain to us about the entire process taken make tea. I taped the whole process and it was very interesting to learn about the types of tea that actually exist. Some I never heard of until my visit to the factory, and just before our tour ends, we get into the room, and we're told about the different tea levels, the tea sold in the local market and the tea that is exported. At the end of the tour we were complimented by a hot cup of tea. That was very yummy. And Im not even a tea drinker. My husband and I bought some tea gift packages for our loved ones. They also have a restaurant, in case you were hungry and wanted to have lunch or something. We didn't try it, but the smell of the food was delicious. You will not be asked to pay for the tour, nor for the tour guide, but we felt that it will be nice to give our tour guide a nice tip, for her friendly way of explaining things to us.

The trip from Kandy to Nuwara Eliya takes you through beautiful water falls and hills where the tea estates are located. We stoped at Glenloch tea factory, where the guide explained us thoroughly the process of tea manufacturing and how the tea is graded. Then we were invited to taste a cup of pure tea. You can buy many varieties of tea, but they are a bit overpriced. You can enjoy your cup of tea on a beautiful terrace overlooking the tea plantation. A useful and enjoyable stop on your trip.
